Title: Colorado Riverbed Case
Publisher: Published by University of Utah - J. Willard Marriott Library
Article Text:
%newline%Transcripts of the Colorado Riverbed Case. This case grew out of a desire by the State of Utah to determine who owned the bed of the Colorado River. Utah wanted to drill for oil and for other economic purposes in the bed of the river%comma% but it first had to be determined who owned it%comma% Utah or the United States. This hinged on whether the Colorado could be declared a navigable or a non-navigable river. The U.S. Supreme Court began acquiring testimony in October 1929. The final decree was issued in 1931%comma% giving possession of the riverbed to the United States in non-navigable sections of the river in Utah. Possession of the riverbed in navigable sections of the basin was given to the State of Utah.

%newline%

This digital presentation is drawn from the holdings of the Marriott Library%comma% which has one of the largest Dard Hunter collections in the world.

Title: Harmonia Macrocosmica
Publisher: Published by University of Utah - J. Willard Marriott Library
Article Text:
%newline%Harmonia Macrocosmica%comma% by Andreas Cellarius%comma% was first printed in 1660. The University of Utah copy is from the 1661 edition. Along with accompanying text in Latin%comma% Harmonia contains double-folio hand-painted color plates depicting cosmographic theories of astronomers such as Aratus (315 bce – 240 bce)%comma% Ptolemy (90 – 168)%comma% Nicolaus Copernicus (1473-1543)%comma% Tycho Brahe (1546-1601)%comma% and others.

Title: Karl Bodmer Aquatint Collection
Publisher: Published by University of Utah - J. Willard Marriott Library
Article Text:
%newline%Karl Bodmer created over 150 watercolors during the 1832 -1834 expedition through the American west by Prince Maximilian zu Wied. For more than a century%comma% Bodmer's aquatints have remained a major source of information regarding Plains Indian culture. These works of art were also instrumental in creating the romantic perceptions and misconceptions of these peoples%comma% which endure to this day in art%comma% film%comma% and literature.

As early as the 1930s someone began the tradition of leaving a metal box in the grotto where travelers could write their names on notebooks and pieces of paper%comma% many of which are a "who's who" of early river runners.

Title: Albert Tissandier Collection
Publisher: Published by University of Utah - Utah Museum of Fine Arts
Article Text:
%newline%Images from Albert Tissandier's trips to North America during 1885 and 1886. Tissandier was born in France in 1839 and died in 1906. A French visitor to the American West in the 1880s%comma% he left a series of pencil drawings of still-recognizable locales in and near Utah. The Utah Museum of Fine Arts holds what may be the most complete collection of these appealing works.

Title: Civilian Conservation Corps in Utah
Publisher: Published by Department of Heritage and Arts
Article Text:
%newline%The Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC)%comma% a New Deal program%comma% operated from 1933 until 1942. The CCC provided jobs and training to young men (primarily between the ages of 18 and 25) and made improvements on public land. Each of the 116 CCC camps established in Utah employed about 200 men. The CCC built campgrounds%comma% worked on erosion control%comma% fought forest fires%comma% planted trees%comma% and did many more projects. Many of these projects still benefit Americans today.

%newline%

Title: Utah Governor's Olympic Collection

Article Text:

Governor met with President George W. Bush%comma% members of his cabinet%comma% representatives and athletes from 77 countries%comma% guests of state%comma% and the people of Utah.

The Regional History Center is a one of a kind center in the state of Utah and the western states region. The Regional History Center has three photo collections. The Regional History Collection is made up of photos given to the center by various donors%comma% the Vernal Express Collection is photographs that were in the local newspaper%comma% and the Thorne Collection is a large collection from early photographer Leo Thorne.

Title: Frank Lloyd Wright: Wasmuth Portfolio
Publisher: Published by University of Utah - J. Willard Marriott Library
Article Text:
%newline%The Wasmuth Portfolio was a collaborative effort between Frank Lloyd Wright and Ernst Wasmuth%comma% a German publisher. It is a complete folio of Wright's work to date%comma% and was published in 1910-11. The collection of Wright's houses and commercial buildings received far more attention and praise in Europe than in the United States. Contemporary architects called it "the most important book of the century."

Title: Trails of Hope: Overland Biographies 1846-1869
Publisher: Published by Brigham Young University - Harold B. Lee Library
Article Text:
%newline%Trails of Hope: Overland Diaries and Letters%comma% 1846–1869 is a collection of the original writings of 49 voyagers on the Mormon%comma% California%comma% Oregon%comma% and Montana trails who wrote while traveling on the trail. Some diarists speak with uncommon eloquence and others with maddening brevity%comma% while telling their stories of persistence and pain%comma% birth and death%comma% God and gold%comma% dust and debris%comma% bugs and buffalo%comma% love and laughter%comma% and trail tedium. Accompanying the original diary images and their searchable transcripts are 43 contemporary maps; seven trail guides; 82 photographs%comma% watercolors and art sketches; four essays on the Mormon and California trails%comma% maps and trail guides; suggested readings for further discovery; and brief biographies of 45 of the 49 diarists.

Title: Eisenhower Communiques
Publisher: Published by Brigham Young University - Harold B. Lee Library
Article Text:
%newline%These communiqués were designed mainly as a guide to correspondents covering battlefront activities%comma% though they also served to keep various branches of the Allied forces informed and coordinated. (They were not secret or confidential.) The reports do not describe the local horror and suffering from bombs and bullets but provide an overall%comma% almost businesslike%comma% account of the Allied advance across France%comma% the Netherlands%comma% and Germany

Title: John Donne Sermons
Publisher: Published by Brigham Young University - Harold B. Lee Library
Article Text:
%newline%Though John Donne is known to his twenty-first century reader primarily as a poet%comma% it is as a preacher that he reached his highest fame during his lifetime%comma% and for his sermons that he expected to be remembered. From his first extant sermon in April 1615%comma% delivered before Queen Anne when Donne was a newly-minted clergyman%comma% to his famous last sermon Death's Duell %comma% Donne's homiletic work displays a remarkable range of learning and interest. At the heart of Donne's sermons lies an energy of mind that exhorts its audience to attend%comma% to reflect%comma% and even to wrestle with God after the example of Donne himself.

%newline%
AMP Image Version: <amp-img src="../images/collection_images/collection1094.jpg" alt="A Sermon Preached at Saint Dunstans" width="335" height="337" layout = "responsive"></amp-img>
Image Description: A Sermon Preached at Saint Dunstans

Title: Trails of Hope: Overland Trail Guides 1846-1869
Publisher: Published by Brigham Young University - Harold B. Lee Library
Article Text:
%newline%Trails of Hope: Overland Diaries and Letters%comma% 1846–1869 is a collection of the original writings of 49 voyagers on the Mormon%comma% California%comma% Oregon%comma% and Montana trails who wrote while traveling on the trail. Some diarists speak with uncommon eloquence and others with maddening brevity%comma% while telling their stories of persistence and pain%comma% birth and death%comma% God and gold%comma% dust and debris%comma% bugs and buffalo%comma% love and laughter%comma% and trail tedium. Accompanying the original diary images and their searchable transcripts are 43 contemporary maps; seven trail guides; 82 photographs%comma% watercolors and art sketches; four essays on the Mormon and California trails%comma% maps and trail guides; suggested readings for further discovery; and brief biographies of 45 of the 49 diarists.

%newline%
AMP Image Version: <amp-img src="../images/collection_images/collection1095.jpg" alt="The Latter-day Saints' emigrants' guide" width="306" height="437" layout = "responsive"></amp-img>
Browse Link: %newline%Browse all records in Trails of Hope: Overland Trail Guides 1846-1869

%newline%

Publisher: Published by Southern Utah University - Sherratt Library
Article Text:
%newline%

Originally the Beaver Branch of Brigham Young University%comma% the school became independent in 1908 and was renamed Murdock Academy. Housed in the buildings of Fort Cameron%comma% a former military base outside of Beaver%comma% Utah%comma% it offered a 4 year high school program. This privately owned school closed in 1922 when the new public Beaver High School was opened.

Title: Topaz Japanese-American Relocation Center Digital Collection
Publisher: Published by Utah State University - Merrill-Cazier Library
Article Text:
%newline%In 1942 shortly after the bombing of Pearl Harbor%comma% over 110%comma%000 people of Japanese ancestry were forcibly removed from California%comma% Oregon%comma% and Washington and confined to relocation centers. One of these relocation centers was the Topaz Relocation Center located on 17%comma%500 acres in the middle of the Sevier Desert just outside of Delta%comma% Utah. Until the camp closed in Oct. 1945%comma% over 8%comma%000 men%comma% women and children lived%comma% worked%comma% and went to school there; over 100 of its residents volunteered for and served in the U.S. armed forces.

%newline%

Publisher: Published by Utah State University - Merrill-Cazier Library
Article Text:
%newline%A century's worth of images from Utah State University's past (1880s-1980s) depict the changing faces and landscape on campus%comma% from the university's early years when women's gym classes and military cadet formations took place inside Old Main's auditorium (1890s)%comma% to 1906 when football scrimmages were held on Old Main's front lawn%comma% to the 1920's when the campus housed a poultry yard and hosted milking contests%comma% to the 1960s' student bathtub races%comma% and up through the 1980s when the University Inn was built. Teachers%comma% students%comma% activities%comma% clubs%comma% athletics%comma% ceremonies%comma% buildings%comma% and more are featured in over 2%comma%000 photographs collected by a former director of the Library's Special Collections and Archives%comma% A. J. Simmonds.

%newline%

Browse Link: %newline%Browse all records in Utah State University Historical Photograph Collection

Title: Death Valley Region Photograph Collection
Publisher: Published by Utah State University - Merrill-Cazier Library
Article Text:
%newline%This small collection of black and white photographs of the Death Valley area of Nevada and California was taken mainly in the late 1920s by "Shorty" Harris or one of his associates. Featuring buildings%comma% a hearse%comma% a gravestone%comma% and other scenes from the ghost towns of Rhyolite%comma% Aurora%comma% and Calico%comma% the Death Valley Region Photograph Collection consists of eleven silver gelatin POP prints purchased from Amalgre Books of Bloomington%comma% Indiana in April of 1997.

Title: Utah's Most Elusive: Hard-to-Find Government and Scientific Reports
Publisher: Published by Utah State University - Merrill-Cazier Library
Article Text:
%newline%This digital collection brings to light many elusive reports written about Utah by local%comma% state and government agencies%comma% but not widely distributed. Full of interesting%comma% significant research and information%comma% these hard-to-find reports provide baseline and historical data as well as viewpoints from earlier eras. Each title is presented as a color image%comma% with fully searchable text%comma% a printable pdf version%comma% and accompanying metadata record with descriptive summary%comma% subject headings%comma% etc.

Title: Facing the Color Line: Race and Ethnicity in Cache Valley
Publisher: Published by Utah State University - Merrill-Cazier Library
Article Text:
%newline%What was it like to be a minority in Cache Valley during the Civil Rights era? To support this year's Common Literature Experience%comma% Merrill-Cazier Library presents this digital collection of interviews%comma% images%comma% and documents illustrating attitudes toward race and ethnicity in Cache Valley before and after the events in Little Rock%comma% Arkansas in 1957 described by Melba Beals in the book Warriors Don't Cry.

Title: Grouse Creek Cultural Survey: Mormon Buckaroo Territory%comma% 1985
Publisher: Published by Utah State University - Merrill-Cazier Library
Article Text:
%newline%In the summer of 1985 a team of folklife specialists (folklorists%comma% architectural historians%comma% & historians) from the Library of Congress and Utah spent a couple of weeks living in Grouse Creek%comma% interviewing its people and recording its history and culture. The survey's interviews%comma% photographs%comma% slides%comma% and field notes presented here are digital facsimiles of originals deposited at Utah State University 's Fife Folklore Archives as Folk Collection 21.

Title: The Ridgway Brothers: Explorers%comma% Scientists%comma% and Illustrators
Publisher: Published by Utah State University - Merrill-Cazier Library
Article Text:
%newline%This digital collection highlights the art work%comma% correspondence%comma% and research of the Ridgway brothers%comma% John and Robert%comma% late nineteenth century naturalists and illustrators of the American West. In 1864%comma% 14 year old Robert began a correspondence with noted naturalist Spencer Baird. This relationship led to Robert being asked to join geologist Clarence King as the zoologist of the 1867-69 United States Geological Fortieth Parallel Survey. Ridgway joined the expedition in San Francisco after traveling by steamboat through the Caribbean and the Isthmus of Panama. He accompanied the expedition through the Sierra Nevada Mountains%comma% over the Great Basin desert and ended up in Utah . He left the expedition in fall of 1868 and returned the next summer to collect specimens around the Great Salt Lake and Wasatch Mountains.

%newline%

Title: Utah Governors Executive Orders and Proclamations
Publisher: Published by Utah State Archives
Article Text:
%newline%

This series contains the official copies of executive orders and proclamations issued by the Governor. Executive orders afford a method for reacting to and preparing a plan of action for sudden problems or changing events which require the Governor's prompt attention. Their issuance provides an established conventional means of responding to these events. Through the executive order%comma% the Governor also creates mechanisms to implement the regulations and establish organizations to perform activities of the government in some specific way. Proclamations are more broad statements of position. They provide a formal means to report to the general public that the Governor has responded to an event in a specific manner. Frequently proclamations are issued to pay tribute or to express formal observance of holidays or other noteworthy occasions.

%newline%
Browse Link: %newline%Browse all records in Utah Governors Executive Orders and Proclamations

Title: Homer Jones Photographs
Publisher: Published by Southern Utah University - Sherratt Library
Article Text:
%newline%

Homer Jones grew up helping his father%comma% Randall L. Jones%comma% photograph and promote the scenic beauty of Utah's national parks. He married Belle Macfarlane%comma% and they established Zion Photo Shop on Cedar's Main Street%comma% where they did studio photography for over fifty years. The studio images are available in Special Collections in the Southern Utah University Library. The images searchable here represent the scenery he learned to love from his father and events in the schools and communities of southern Utah.

%newline%

Title: Practicing Medicine: A Historical Glimpse at Utah and Beyond
Publisher: Published by Utah State University - Merrill-Cazier Library
Article Text:
%newline%Gawande's candid book about medicine exemplifies essay writing at its best and is Utah State University 's choice for the 2007 Common Literature Experience. Created to support reading and discussion of Complications%comma% the digital collection Practicing Medicine: A Historical Glimpse at Utah and Beyond explores three centuries of medical practice and instruction%comma% with particular focus on Utah. These historical materials take us back to the roots of medical practice and a time when remedies consisted of such easily recognized ingredients as "earth-worms%comma% well washed." Perhaps they will lend perspective to%comma% and renewed appreciation for%comma% the unpronounceable medicines and modern treatments%comma% however imperfect%comma% that Dr. Gawande and his colleagues apply today.

%newline%

Title: Arabic Papyrus%comma% Parchment%comma% and Paper Collection
Publisher: Published by University of Utah - J. Willard Marriott Library
Article Text:
%newline%The Arabic Papyrus%comma% Parchment & Paper Collection is the largest of its kind in the United States%comma% containing 770 Arabic papyrus documents%comma% 1300 Arabic paper documents%comma% and several pieces on parchment. The collection was acquired by Prof. Aziz Suriyal Atiya%comma% founder of the Middle East Center and the Middle East Library. A large number of pieces date to the period between 700 and 850 CE. The collection includes a significant number of documents from the pre-Ottoman period and thus offers unique source material on the political%comma% economic%comma% religious and intellectual life of Egypt during the first two centuries of Islamic rule and the period up to Ottoman domination.

%newline%

Article Text:
%newline%This collection contains large-scale%comma% detailed maps from 1867 into the early 20th century depicting the commercial%comma% industrial%comma% and residential sections of many Utah cities. They were designed in 1866 by surveyor D.A. Sanborn to assist fire insurance agents in determining the risk associated with insuring a particular property. The map surveyors meticulously documented the structural evidence of urbanization - building by building%comma% block by block%comma% and community by community.

Title: Showgirls Collection
Publisher: Published by University of Nevada%comma% Las Vegas%comma% University Libraries
Article Text:
%newline%The Las Vegas Showgirl%comma% and the shows which exemplified them%comma% have a history all their own. From the distinct theatrical traditions of burlesque%comma% vaudeville%comma% dance and music halls%comma% the French cancan%comma% comic opera and operetta%comma% Broadway%comma% speakeasies and nightclubs%comma% and movies%comma% came a cosmopolitan adult entertainment popular in New York%comma% Hollywood%comma% Paris%comma% Miami Beach%comma% Rio%comma% and ultimately Las Vegas%comma% where it seemed to become a permanent fixture of this town's almost timeless firmament of entertainment. The drawings exhibited here illustrate the shows and productions that epitomize Las Vegas.

%newline%

Title: Southern Nevada and Las Vegas History in Maps
Publisher: Published by University of Nevada%comma% Las Vegas%comma% University Libraries
Article Text:
%newline%The historic map collection housed in the UNLV Libraries' Division of Special Collection dates from the 17th century to the present%comma% including significant collections concerning the exploration of the American West%comma% the American Southwest%comma% Nevada%comma% and Southern Nevada. This collection contains the original published reports of the great 19th century U.S. government surveys of the West%comma% as well as the series of maps and atlases by Fremont%comma% Emory%comma% Beckwith%comma% Warren and Wheeler that accompanied the published accounts.

%newline%

Title: Las Vegas and Water in the West
Publisher: Published by University of Nevada%comma% Las Vegas%comma% University Libraries
Article Text:
%newline%Las Vegas%comma% Spanish for "the meadows%comma%" was always about water. Its natural springs were a watering stop%comma% for wandering Native Americans%comma% Spanish and American traders%comma% Mormon settlers%comma% ranchers%comma% and Senator William Clark and his San Pedro%comma% Los Angeles & Salt Lake Railroad. As the railroad depot grew into a city%comma% the pressure upon the water supply would be a permanent aspect of development. The collection presented here documents this history back to the 19th century military and scientific surveys conducted by the U.S. government%comma% directed ultimately toward the future settlement and exploitation of the West. Associated with the scientific expeditions to map a route for the transcontinental railroad were studies to explore the feasibility of irrigation to support agriculture.

%newline%

Browse Link: %newline%Browse all records in Las Vegas and Water in the West

Title: Utah Division of Animal Industry Brand Books
Publisher: Published by Utah State Archives
Article Text:
%newline%Brand books contain all livestock brands and ear marks registered with the State Department of Agriculture. Livestock is assumed to include all types of animals raised for pleasure or for profit. The 1917 law was the first to specifically mention cattle%comma% horses%comma% and mules as livestock [ Laws of Utah%comma% chapter 105 (1917)]%comma% although the brands of these and perhaps other animals may have been recorded before then. Subsequent revisions of the brand law expanded the definition of livestock to include several other animals.

%newline%

Title: Utah Board of Pardons: Prisoner Pardon Application Case Files
Publisher: Published by Utah State Archives
Article Text:
%newline%Case files consist of letters to the Governor%comma% a formal application for a pardon%comma% petitions and letters of support from the public and officials connected to the case and during the first 40 years%comma% case files often contained court transcripts%comma% biographical sketches%comma% prison evaluations and a wide variety of related documentation. Cases illustrate the process of review by the board of cases of prisoners incarcerated in the Utah prison system to determine if they should be released before their regular sentence ended. Documents contain personal data about the prisoner%comma% criminal activity%comma% family background and evaluation of the prisoner's adjustment to incarceration.

Title: Encyclopedia of Mormonism
Publisher: Published by Brigham Young University - Harold B. Lee Library
Article Text:
%newline%The idea for this reference work began with an inquiry from Macmillan in 1987%comma% when Charles Smith approached Professor S. Kent Brown at Brigham Young University (the two knew each other from working together on the Coptic Encyclopedia). Following a successful meeting with BYU President Jeffrey R. Holland%comma% a publication agreement was negotiated%comma% and in 1988 a Board of Editors%comma% with Daniel H. Ludlow as Editor-in-Chief%comma% was appointed. Three years later%comma% the Encyclopedia appeared%comma% bearing a 1992 publication date. It remains the most encyclopedic coverage of Mormonism ever produced.

Title: Mormon Missionary Diaries
Publisher: Published by Brigham Young University - Harold B. Lee Library
Article Text:
%newline%One of the great values that Mormon missionary diaries give us is the insight into the lives of ordinary people%comma% missionaries and the people they labored among. We find deep religious insights set against cultural and social biases%comma% often fermenting in misunderstandings due to language gaps of considerable proportions. But beyond the daily cares and cycles of the lives of common people are insights into the economic and political worlds they inhabited. Poverty%comma% inflation%comma% population mobility%comma% family and community structure%comma% as well as religious attitudes are just a sample of the knowledge that can be gained through the study of these missionary journals.

%newline%

Title: Nevada Test Site Oral History Project
Publisher: Published by University of Nevada%comma% Las Vegas%comma% University Libraries
Article Text:
%newline%The Nevada Test Site Oral History Project at the University of Nevada%comma% Las Vegas is a comprehensive program dedicated to documenting%comma% preserving and disseminating the remembered past of persons affiliated with and affected by the Nevada Test Site during the era of Cold War nuclear testing. From September 2003 through January 2008 a wide range of oral history narrators participated in the project including: national laboratory scientists & engineers; labor trades and support personnel; cabinet-level officials%comma% military personnel & corporate executives; Native American tribal & spiritual leaders; peace activists and protesters; Nevada ranchers%comma% families & communities downwind of the test site.

Title: Latino/Latina Voices
Publisher: Published by Utah State University - Merrill-Cazier Library
Article Text:
%newline%Cache Valley%comma% Utah is home to a rich and varied Latino population whose voice is often underrepresented in local repositories. To rectify this%comma% in the summer/fall 2007 Utah State University's Special Collections and Archives collected the voices of 45 local Latino/a residents which are now presented in this digital collection. The interviews feature people originally from Mexico%comma% Guatemala%comma% Brazil%comma% California and yes%comma% even Utah. The interviewees talk about family traditions%comma% religion%comma% jobs and interests%comma% as well as challenges associated with relocation%comma% cultural identity and cultural differences.

Title: Utah State University Special Collections Digital Exhibits
Publisher: Published by Utah State University - Merrill-Cazier Library
Article Text:
%newline%The materials housed by the Special Collections & Archives have been collected for the benefit of the public and are available for use by researchers. Historically%comma% however%comma% the public has not been aware of the research possibilities of archival material. Making digitized collections available through our website publicizes the many opportunities for use of our materials. Many of the materials in Special Collections are too fragile to allow repeated close examination. With digital technology we are able to provide access to these documents over the internet and to avoid inevitable wear and tear on these fragile resources.

Title: Mountain West Digital Library - Collection: Brigham Young University Encoded Archival Description (EAD) Finding Aids
Publisher: Published by Brigham Young University - Harold B. Lee Library
Article Text:
%newline%

The Society of American Archivists glossary defines finding aids as:

%newline%

Finding aids typically have two components: an overview of the collection and a detailed inventory of the contents of the collection. The overview of the collection describes who created the materials%comma% the scope of the collection%comma% the arrangement of the collection%comma% and any access restrictions on the materials. The detailed inventory describes the contents of the collection at the series-level and the file or item-level. Finding aids are created to help researchers gain access to the materials.

%newline%

Title: Welcome Home%comma% Howard! (Howard Hughes Photograph Collection)
Publisher: Published by University of Nevada%comma% Las Vegas%comma% University Libraries
Article Text:
%newline%In 1996%comma% Special Collections acquired from the Howard Hughes Corporation in Las Vegas the Hughes account and reference files of Dick Hannah%comma% the Byoir Vice President and account executive who handled Howard Hughes's publicity. Like other Hughes agents%comma% Hannah did far more than his title would imply. He not only directed public relations by drafting countless news releases and preparing mountains of press kits with sets of "authorized" photos%comma% he gathered enormous amounts of information concerning what was written about Hughes or about subjects in which Hughes had interest.

%newline%

Title: Cookery and Culture
Publisher: Published by Utah State University - Merrill-Cazier Library
Article Text:
%newline%The digitized historical cookbooks in this collection date from the 1700s to the 1900s. Mostly American and British%comma% they contain not only recipes%comma% but also elegant engravings of table settings and cooking paraphernalia%comma% home remedies and cure-all tonics%comma% instructions on managing servants%comma% and more. In short%comma% these gastronomical treasures reveal much about the societies and economic times that created them.

%newline%

Title: Elsner Sculptures and Sketchbooks
Publisher: Published by Utah State University - Merrill-Cazier Library
Article Text:
%newline%Explore the artistic universe of sculptor Larry E. Elsner as he invented%comma% explored%comma% and clarified ideas about form in hundreds of exquisitely drawn studies in seventy journals from the 1960s to the 1990s. Handwritten travel notes%comma% poetry%comma% technical notes%comma% quotes from other artists%comma% and thoughts about his own artwork and life intertwine with the drawings to form a diary of Elsner's life.

%newline%

Title: Weber State University Student Newspapers
Publisher: Published by Weber State University - Stewart Library
Article Text:
%newline%Weber's current student newspaper%comma% the Signpost%comma% first appeared on September 29%comma% 1937. For two years prior to that time%comma% campus news was disseminated via announcements posted on a bulletin board known as the "Signpost". As a result%comma% the masthead of the first issue of the paper itself featured a rudimentary wooden sign with the title spelled out in rustic-looking letters. Over the years the paper has been published continuously%comma% though the look%comma% size and style has changed several times.

Title: Wilson W. Sorensen Collection of Historical Photographs of Utah Valley University
Publisher: Published by Utah Valley University Library
Article Text:
%newline%The Wilson W. Sorensen Collection of Historical Photographs of Utah Valley University contains images that trace the history of UVU from 1942 to 1982. Wilson W. Sorensen was president of the school during that time%comma% and donated these photographs that document the changing missions%comma% and many names%comma% of the school%comma% from Central Utah Vocational School and Utah Trade and Technical Institute%comma% to Utah Technical College at Provo to Utah Technical College at Provo/Orem. After President Sorensen retired in 1982%comma% the school became Utah Valley Community College%comma% then Utah Valley State College%comma% and now Utah Valley University.

This collection contains private collections from individuals such as Elmo Geary's history of drama and theater in Castle Valley%comma% John Niebergall's "Then and Now" pictures of the Manti-LaSal Forest and other areas of Emery County%comma% and many others that showcase the history of the area.

Publisher: Published by Utah State University - Merrill-Cazier Library
Article Text:
%newline%One bear was very well known to all of the local sheepherders of Cache Valley%comma% Utah. At first they called him Old Three Toe and then later Old Ephraim. He had a deformed foot with only three toes which made it very easy for the sheepherders to know when Old Ephraim attacked their sheep. In 1913 Frank Clark decided to catch and kill Old Ephraim. But at nine feet and eleven inches tall%comma% Old Ephraim was a very large bear%comma% and he was clever. Catching him did not turn out to be easy.

%newline%

Title: Utah Council of Land Surveyors
Publisher: Published by Utah Council of Land Surveyors
Article Text:
%newline%

With the infusion of high technology instrumentation into our profession we are beginning to embrace the broader Geomatics definition while still holding onto the traditional Surveying definition; both are applicable. "Geomatics encompasses disciplines that rely on geospatial data such as: surveying%comma% civil engineering%comma% cartography%comma% land information systems%comma% geodesy%comma% and remote sensing." "Surveying is the art%comma% science%comma% and technology of locating or establishing the relative position of points%comma% lines%comma% or elevations%comma% at%comma% on%comma% above%comma% or below the surface of the earth%comma% on the water or land."

%newline%

Our mission statement: "To protect and promote the Land Surveying Profession by setting high standards and providing education for the members and general public."

Title: Utah Division of State Archives Oaths of Office
Publisher: Published by Utah State Archives
Article Text:
%newline%State officers are required by both the federal and state constitutions to take an oath of office. The Constitution of the United States requires members of the legislature as well as all executive and judicial officers of the states to be bound by oath or affirmation to support the federal Constitution (Article VI%comma% clause 3). The Constitution of Utah specifies the wording of the oath to be taken by "all officers made elective or appointive by this Constitution or by the laws made in pursuance thereof%comma% before entering upon the duties of their respective offices" (Article IV%comma% section 10)

%newline%

Title: Latter-Day Saints' Millennial Star
Publisher: Published by Brigham Young University - Harold B. Lee Library
Article Text:
%newline%The Millennial Star was the longest running Latter-day Saint (LDS) periodical%comma% published continuously for 130 years until discontinued in 1970 with the overhaul of all the LDS magazines. It was inaugurated by the Twelve at the beginning of their great mission to England. Brigham Young and his fellow members of the Twelve landed in Liverpool on April 6%comma% 1840%comma% the tenth anniversary of the Church. Eight days later they began a series of meetings in Preston in which they resolved to publish a monthly periodical to be called the Latter-day Saints Millennial Star.

%newline%

Title: Frederick William Reynolds Lectures

Article Text:
%newline%The annual F.W. Reynolds Lectureships at the University of Utah serve a double purpose. First%comma% through a distinguished member of its faculty%comma% the University presents an important yearly offering to the public. Second%comma% the Lectureship commemorates in a fitting way the unique service of Professor Reynolds to the institution and to the State. The selection committee acts upon recommendations of the Deans who are made responsible for nominating faculty members of outstanding accomplishments in their schools. The University presents the lecture through the medium of its Extension Division. Tthe Reynolds Lectureship has now become firmly established as a University function " promoted and administered by the University.

Title: University of Utah Rare Books Collection
Publisher: Published by University of Utah - J. Willard Marriott Library
Article Text:
%newline%The Rare Books Division of Special Collections holds more than 80%comma%000 books%comma% maps and ephemera representing the written record of world history from ancient clay tablet to 21st century artists' books. By actively collecting%comma% preserving and digitizing material of historical and aesthetic importance the Rare Books Division provides reference%comma% research and educational access to local%comma% regional and international communities%comma% strengthening the ability of faculty to teach%comma% students to learn%comma% and communities to find common denominators.

Title: Utah American Indian Digital Archive
Publisher: Published by University of Utah - American West Center
Article Text:
%newline%The Utah American Indian Digital Archive (UAIDA) is a gateway to the best resources regarding Utah's Indian tribes. With articles%comma% books%comma% government documents%comma% tribal documents%comma% oral histories%comma% photographs%comma% and maps pertaining to the Northwestern Shoshone%comma% Goshute%comma% Paiute%comma% Utah Navajo%comma% White Mesa%comma% and Ute Indians%comma% this unique archive captures the complicated history of Utah's tribes from multiple perspectives. The project%comma% which stems from forty years of research conducted by the University of Utah's American West Center on behalf of Utah's Indians%comma% offers tribal members%comma% students%comma% and researchers unprecedented access to information about the rich history and culture of Utah's native peoples.

%newline%UAIDA is a joint venture between the American West Center and the J. Willard Marriott Library’s Special Collections Department at the University of Utah%comma% with generous support from the State of Utah’s Division of Indian Affairs and Department of Heritage and Arts.

Title: Mendon (UT): A Page from the Past
Publisher: Published by Mendon (UT)
Article Text:
%newline%

Mendon%comma% Utah is located in northern Utah's beautiful Cache Valley%comma% its many snow-fed streams keeping the valley a lush%comma% cool green for much of the year. Cache Valley%comma% as named in the early 1830s by the fur trappers who first worked these same streams and cached-up their goods near here%comma% has long been a favored resting place. Mendon was to be the first of the new cities established in the Cache Valley during this year of renewed expansion and colonization%comma% following the peaceful conclusion of the so-called "Utah War" of 1858.

%newline%

Title: Utah Office of Vital Records and Statistics. Death Certificates%comma% 1905-1958
Publisher: Published by Utah State Archives
Article Text:
%newline%

The Utah Office of Vital Records and Statistics began issuing death certificates in 1904. A death certificate is the permanent legal record of an individual's death. Each death certificate includes the decedent's full name%comma% date of death%comma% county where death occurred%comma% decedent's race and gender%comma% place and date of birth%comma% marital status%comma% occupation%comma% permanent residence%comma% place and date of burial%comma% time of death%comma% chief cause and contributory factors of death%comma% and if applicable%comma% where illness was contracted and duration of illness. Death certificates also include the names and birthplaces of parents.

%newline%

Title: Extension%comma% Enterprise and Education: The Legacy of Cooperatives and Cooperation in Utah
Publisher: Published by Utah State University - Merrill-Cazier Library
Article Text:
%newline%Co-operatives are voluntary associations jointly-owned and operated for the benefit of those using their services. While the Co-operative Movement was a worldwide phenomena in the 1800s%comma% it was particularly strong and pervasive early on in Utah. Nineteenth-century Utah pioneers embraced the spirit of cooperation%comma% building shared irrigation systems and establishing co-op stores within their communities.

%newline%

Title: Bryner Pioneer Museum%comma% Price (UT)
Publisher: Published by Bryner Pioneer Museum (Price%comma% UT)
Article Text:
%newline%Albert Bryner was the second of three sons of Ulrich and Maria Mathis Bryner. Ulrich gave Albert and his wife Mariah Pace%comma% a plot of land on the corner of 1st South and 1st East on which to build a home. It was completed between 1890 and 1892%comma% whereupon Albert was called on a mission to Germany for the LDS Church. The first floor of the house will be decorated in the 1890's period%comma% and the second floor will be decorated in the 1920's to 1950's era to reflect the history of the people who lived here.

Publisher: Published by Utah State University - Merrill-Cazier Library

Ever since then%comma% bells have been used on various animals throughout the world from goats to chickens to sheep to camels. Title: Menus: The Art of Dining
Publisher: Published by University of Nevada%comma% Las Vegas%comma% University Libraries
Article Text:
%newline%Menus provide a wealth of information beyond their purely aesthetic value and are a particularly rich resource for aspects of cultural and social history. They give us information on the most popular cuisine of a time period and region and are evidence of changing culinary tastes. They can indicate how particular food items have been used regionally%comma% and in the case of notable restaurants can provide evidence of the work of well-known chefs. Design-wise they are examples of the graphic design elements illustrative of a particular historical time period. For students of menu design they can serve as examples of graphic design%comma% placement and layout. Last but not least%comma% they have a purely nostalgic value for those persons who have visited a particular restaurant or hotel and want to re-live that experience by reading through the menu.

%newline%

Browse Link: %newline%Browse all records in Menus: The Art of Dining

Title: Brigham Young University Finding Aids
Publisher: Published by Brigham Young University - Harold B. Lee Library
Article Text:
%newline%

The Society of American Archivists glossary defines finding aids as:

%newline%

Finding aids typically have two components: an overview of the collection and a detailed inventory of the contents of the collection. The overview of the collection describes who created the materials%comma% the scope of the collection%comma% the arrangement of the collection%comma% and any access restrictions on the materials. The detailed inventory describes the contents of the collection at the series-level and the file or item-level. Finding aids are created to help researchers gain access to the materials.

%newline%

Title: Commissioner of Indian War Records Indian War Service Affidavits
Publisher: Published by Utah State Archives
Article Text:
%newline%

In 1909 the legislature passed a law creating a Board of Commissioners of Indian War Records. Their duties were to ascertain the names of the persons who were members of any organization performing military duties during Indian wars or expeditions against the Indians during territorial years. Veterans completed affidavits of service; two witnesses also completed affidavits supporting the facts. The affidavits were then filed in the office of the chairman of the board%comma% the Adjutant General of the State.

%newline%

Title: Salt Lake Community College Student Newspapers
Publisher: Published by Salt Lake Community College Libraries
Article Text:
%newline%The student newspaper for Salt Lake Community College has been published under a number of different names. The Tradesman is the earliest title found to-date and the single issue on file was published in 1959. Tech Topics was published from December 1962 until August 1973. Utah Tech News was published as a supplement to the Murray Eagle for what looks like a single issue in August 1973. Beginning in September 1973 the title became Points West until June 1987. While a new name was being sought from student suggestions the masthead for the paper read No Name Paper for four issues from September to October 1987. The new name decided upon was Horizon which lasted from October 1987 until March 2001. The student newspaper resumed publication under its current name The Globe in October 2001.

Title: Ogden (UT) City Recorder Birth Register
Publisher: Published by Utah State Archives
Article Text:
%newline%The Ogden City Recorder kept a register of births occurring within Ogden which included a name%comma% parents%comma% date of birth%comma% residence%comma% race%comma% sex%comma% whether stillborn or live birth%comma% name of attending physician and remarks. The recorder also collected supplemental information confirming births in the form of affidavits and birth certificates%comma% including some for births prior to 1890. These were interleaved%comma% taped and glued to the pages of the original register. Later on%comma% a second copy of the register was typewritten and is included in this series. The recorder began this register before an 1898 law which required filing reports of birth with the county clerk (Revised Statutes of Utah 1898%comma% Title 57%comma% p. 474-475). In 1904%comma% a new law superseded the county registers with uniform birth certificates kept permanently by the Vital Records and Statistics office.

%newline% 

%newline%

Article Text:
%newline%Design Workshop®%comma% a Denver-based landscape architecture firm%comma% has been creating "sustainable places of timeless beauty" since 1969. The firm's numerous awards reflects its successful innovations in land planning and design. To mark its 40th anniversary in 2010%comma% Design Workshop partnered with Utah State University to create the Design Workshop Landscape Architecture Archive which includes this digital collection as well as a physical archive housed in Merrill-Cazier Library's Special Collections and Archives

Title: Intermountain Indian School
Publisher: Published by Utah State University - Merrill-Cazier Library
Article Text:
%newline%In 1948 Bushnell Hospital in Brigham City%comma% Utah was transformed into what would become the Intermountain Indian School%comma% or%comma% the "world's largest boarding school." The school opened its doors in January 1950 to five hundred Navajo students. Educational goals were to teach English and basic academic disciplines as well as vocational skills which%comma% it was believed%comma% would facilitate assimilation into mainstream America.

Title: Lincoln Ellison%comma% U.S. Forest Service
Publisher: Published by Utah State University - Merrill-Cazier Library
Article Text:
%newline%“Let us remember that there is an ethical element in sound land use. To us as human beings—rather than as animals—this ethical element may well be as important as the element of survival.” -- Lincoln Ellison in his 1955 inaugural address "Our Weight in the Balance of Nature" to the Utah Academy of Sciences.

Ellison’s extraordinary passion for nature and the outdoors shines clearly in his journals%comma% correspondence%comma% and scientific writing. A diarist from a young age%comma% Ellison grew up in an age of letter writers and was himself an eloquent writer. Those of his writings included in this digital collection show the thinking of an early ecological pioneer. They chronicle his ideas about man and the environment%comma% recreation%comma% wilderness and family life. They also represent a narrative about the western United States during the Depression and World War II.

Born in Portland%comma% Oregon%comma% Ellison grew up in California and worked for the United States Forest Service throughout the western United States during the 1930s-1950s. He was the director of the Great Basin Experiment Station in Ephraim%comma% Utah and later moved to Ogden to manage the region’s range research program.This collection was generously donated to Utah State University by his daughter%comma% Liane Norman%comma% whose full biography of Ellison entitled Lincoln Ellison Director%comma% Great Basin Branch Experiment Station 1938—45 is included.

%newline%

Image Description: Blue Ridge Mountains%comma% Shenandoah National Park

Title: Utah Statehood Constitutional Convention State Constitution
Publisher: Published by Utah State Archives
Article Text:
%newline%This series is the official or "engrossed" copy of the Utah State Constitution adopted by the Constitutional Convention in 1895. Congress passed an Enabling Act in 1894 that set out the requirements for the Utah Territory to achieve statehood. The main requirement was the adoption of an acceptable constitution. The Constitutional Convention met to formulate such a document from 4 March to 8 May1895. Convention delegates debated a variety of issues related to crafting a constitution%comma% including the structure of state government%comma% the separation of church and state%comma% and woman suffrage.

%newline%

Article Text:
%newline%This series contains a variety of records that document work done by state agencies in response to mandates set by the Little Hoover Commission%comma% which was tasked with reorganizing Utah State Government in the 1960's. The records in this series include correspondence between agencies and the commission%comma% as well as state agency meeting minutes pertaining to discussions focused on improving efficiency and a variety of reorganization issues and scenarios. Based on this information many state government agencies produced statements and recommendations to the Little Hoover Commission %comma% several of which can be found in this series.

Title: William D. Hurst Papers
Publisher: Published by Utah State University - Merrill-Cazier Library
Article Text:
%newline%

U.S. Forester William Daly Hurst's distinguished service with the Forest Service spanned four decades (1937-1976) of changes in policies related to multiple use and resource conservation%comma% including the grazing permit controversy of 1957-1958. The William D. Hurst Digital Collection features Hurst's daily diaries%comma% files%comma% and calendars%comma% providing an in-depth look at his life and work in the Forest Service.

%newline%

Born in Parowan%comma% Utah%comma% on October 15%comma% 1915%comma% Hurst grew up in Panguitch%comma% Utah%comma% leaving in 1934 to attend Utah State Agricultural College in Logan%comma% Utah. While still earning his B.S. in Forestry there%comma% Hurst began his career with the Forest Service as an Administrative Guard for the Wasatch National Forest in 1937; he became the District Ranger for the Manila Ranger District%comma% Ashley National Forest in 1942. World War II Army service in Japan interrupted his forestry work from 1945 to 1946. After discharge he returned to the Forest Service as Staff Officer of the Cache National Forest%comma% a position he held until 1950 when he became Supervisor of the Ashley National Forest.

%newline%

In 1955%comma% Mr. Hurst left the beauty of northern Utah for Washington D.C. where he served as an Assistant Chief for Range Management. He returned two years later to Utah where he replaced Floyd Iverson as Chief of Range and Wildlife Management in Region 4 and subsequently was appointed Deputy Regional Forester for the Intermountain Region in 1962. In 1966%comma% Hurst became Regional Forester for the Southwestern Region%comma% remaining in this position until his retirement in 1976.

%newline%

Besides reading about Hurst's daily work via his written diaries%comma% files%comma% and calendars%comma% users of this collection can hear Hurst speak about his experiences in Logan Canyon and with the Forest Service through two oral history interviews recorded in 2008 and 2009.

%newline%
AMP Image Version: <amp-img src="../images/collection_images/collection1638.jpg" alt="William D. Hurst day planner" width="177" height="292" layout = "responsive"></amp-img>
Browse Link: %newline%Browse all records in William D. Hurst Papers

Title: Taylor Woolley Photograph Collection
Publisher: Published by Department of Heritage and Arts
Article Text:
%newline%This collection comprises 60 images taken by Utah architect%comma% Taylor Woolley. The majority of the images are at Frank Lloyd Wright's home%comma% Taliesin I%comma% c. 1911-1912. Woolley worked under Frank Lloyd Wright for a time%comma% traveling with him to Europe and later helping in the construction of Taliesin I in Spring Green%comma% Wisconsin. Woolley captured some unique images of the construction of Taliesin I%comma% both interior and exterior%comma% as well as images showing the intricate details of the home.

%newline%

Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%

David Swing (1864-1945) studied art under his father and Thomas Lindsey%comma% but began his career as a musician. He began to give violin concerts in 1884. He continued to play music in the orchestra of Theodore Thomas%comma% the Pasadena Municipal Band%comma% organizing and directing the Alhambra Municipal Band and Orchestra%comma% and to play violin and cello in the Phoenix Symphony Orchestra. From the start of his musical career until his move to Phoenix%comma% David Swing worked with lithograph firms and as president of an engraving firm. In Phoenix%comma% he eventually gave up his career as a musician to focus on painting desert life. Along with his Golden Gate International Exposition paintings%comma% Swing also painted for Masonic temples%comma% government hospitals and theaters. He continued painting until the end of his life.

%newline%

%newline%

Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%

Lon Megarge was born in Philadelphia in 1883. He changed the spelling of his last name to Megargee and the story of his past while he made his way westward into the Arizona Territory around 1896. Arizona became the 48th state on February 14th%comma% 1912. Megargee was commissioned by the state to paint fifteen large canvases which were installed in the State Capitol building. These paintings portray early Arizona%comma% encompassing landscapes%comma% natural wonders%comma% the customs of Native Americans%comma% historic buildings%comma% and the life of early settlers. The "Five Cs" of Arizona's economy (cattle%comma% citrus%comma% climate%comma% copper and cotton) are represented in many of these paintings. The original paintings are still displayed in the Arizona State Capitol today.

%newline%

%newline%

Note: 1658.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%

In 1957 Arizona made plans to construct a new Capitol building. Believing that the submitted plans for the new Capitol were tombs to the past%comma% Frank Lloyd Wright offered an alternative to the people of Arizona. Wright felt that Arizona's Capitol should inspire the citizens to loftier heights. Wright's architectural dream of the Oasis captures the spirit of his vision - an oasis from the heat of the desert%comma% an oasis from the mediocrity of our past decisions%comma% an oasis for open government and unconstrained ideas. This collection also includes an early version of the Oasis with three spires%comma% a typewritten transcript where Wright expresses his opinions regarding the various plans for Arizona's Capitol Building%comma% and images of the restoration work completed by Kenneth C. Truong.

%newline%

%newline%

%newline%

The USS Arizona became infamous on December 7th%comma% 1941 as the first U.S. battleship sunk during World War II. It continues to be in the forefront of American consciousness as a memorial to the servicemen who died during the war. The Arizona Capitol Museum is home to the silver service that was donated to the USS Arizona by the citizens of this state in 1919. This service is comprised of 59 distinct pieces on display at the Capitol Museum. Documents associated with the service are located in the Arizona State Archives.

%newline%

Note: 1660.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%Since February 1863%comma% when President Abraham Lincoln first recognized the Territory of Arizona as a protectorate of the United States of America%comma% mining has been the backbone of the Arizona economy. And for over a century%comma% the Arizona Geological Survey and its predecessors have collected and archived information on mines and mine activities in Arizona.

%newline%The Mines Collection of the Arizona Geological Survey contains information on thousands of Arizona mines -- only a select few are displayed here. All told%comma% the collection comprises more than 82 linear feet of files filled with old newspaper clippings%comma% accounts of mine histories%comma% geologic reports%comma% mineral assessments%comma% production reports%comma% historic letters inquiring of ore reserves and economic viability%comma% and to a lesser extent%comma% maps%comma% geologic cross-sections%comma% assay reports%comma% mine schematics%comma% and photographs. Most of the files were compiled between 1900 and 1960. These files shine a light into individual mines%comma% which%comma% when taken collectively%comma% illuminate the rich and diverse history of mining and miners in Arizona.

%newline%The earliest miners were prehistoric Native Americans who harvested outcrops of salt%comma% clays%comma% hematite%comma% quartz%comma% obsidian%comma% stone%comma% turquoise%comma% and coal. In the late 1600's%comma% Spanish explorers began the hunt for metallic deposits with especial focus on gold and silver. In 1854%comma% in Ajo%comma% Arizona%comma% the Arizona Mining and Trading Company launched the modern era of hard-rock mining.

%newline%A burgeoning mining industry fostered growth in the Arizona Territory%comma% and by 1864 nearly 25 percent of the male%comma% non-native populace was made up of prospectors. By the 1870's%comma% an uptick in hardrock mining yielded prodigious volumes of copper%comma% lead%comma% zinc%comma% silver and gold ore. In 1912%comma% the newly christened state of Arizona supported 445 active mines%comma% 72 concentrating facilities%comma% and 11 smelters; their gross value that year was nearly 67 million dollars -- equivalent to 1.4 billion dollars in 2006.

%newline%And here at the start of the 21st Century%comma% the important metallic commodities of Arizona --listed in order of decreasing value -- include copper%comma% gold%comma% silver%comma% molybdenum%comma% and lead. Important non-metallic (industrial) minerals -- listed in order of decreasing value -- include sand and gravel%comma% crushed stone%comma% clay%comma% cement%comma% gypsum%comma% lime%comma% perlite%comma% pumice%comma% and salt. Arizona's is world-famous for its turquoise%comma% peridot%comma% petrified wood%comma% and for striking%comma% copper-bearing minerals: turquoise%comma% azurite%comma% malachite. Energy resources of Arizona include coal and small quantities of petroleum and natural gas.

%newline%But copper is king! In 2007%comma% Arizona's copper mines produced more than 750%comma%000 tons of copper with a value of 5.5 billion dollars. Most of the copper mined in Arizona stems from porphyry-copper deposits%comma% which are associated with intrusive igneous rocks similar to granite. The term porphyry describes the typical texture of these rocks%comma% in which individual mineral grains%comma% from about one-tenth inch to a half-inch in size%comma% are fixed in a matrix of smaller grains that are barely visible to the naked eye. Other minerals common to copper porphyry deposits are molybdenum and silver.

%newline%

%newline%
AMP Image Version: <amp-img src="../images/collection_images/collection1660.jpg" alt="Calumet & Arizona Mining Company%comma% Bisbee%comma% Arizona" width="366" height="258" layout = "responsive"></amp-img>
Image Description: Calumet & Arizona Mining Company%comma% Bisbee%comma% Arizona

The minutes of the Pima County Medical Society offer a detailed look into a broad range of medical%comma% social%comma% political and professional issues -- some of these at the local level and many at the national level. Any thorough study of the history of medicine in Arizona will benefit from a careful exploration of these documents.

Not only did these families come early%comma% but they also remain in place%comma% or nearby%comma% to this very day. Their stories provide a unique and fluid account of how this segment of Arizona's culture has adapted to pressures and influences brought about by environmental and political events.

Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%

The Arizona Historical Foundation houses two collections pertaining to Arizona's two World War II Japanese Relocation Camps%comma% Gila River and Poston. Wade Head served as director of the Poston camp from 1942-1944%comma% and his collection focuses on the administration and documentation of camp life. Frances and Mary Montgomery were teachers at Butte High School%comma% located at the Gila River camp. The Montgomery collection contains student photographs and correspondence%comma% yearbooks%comma% and educational materials. This exhibition showcases original artwork%comma% documents and photographs that illustrate the dichotomy of these two collections while honoring the spirit and culture of their American subjects.

%newline%

Article Text:

Ruth Reinhold (1902-1985)%comma% an aviation pioneer%comma% was one of the first woman pilots in Arizona. She marked many milestones%comma% from barnstorming to teaching pilots to fly four-engine bombers during World War II. These images were selected from the 1200 photographs researched and collected for her book Sky Pioneering. It is a remarkable survey of aerial landscapes%comma% pilots%comma% aircraft%comma% airports%comma% landing fields%comma% and aviation events in Arizona dating from the early 1900s through the late 1970s.

Note: 1666.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%

The women of the West were both saints and shady ladies. They did not and could not fit the Victorian models of womanhood. Those artificial standards were impossible to maintain in the newly settled West. It would be ridiculous to ride twenty miles only to leave a calling card%comma% and many of the other rules of conduct were equally inappropriate. While the spirit of gentility – care of family%comma% consideration of others%comma% and moral fiber – was present%comma% the outward appearances could not be kept; therefore%comma% none of these women could truly be considered "ladies." Instead they lived practically and industriously. Famous or "unsung heroines%comma%" their lives and works shaped the form and spirit of the state of Arizona.

%newline%

%newline%
AMP Image Version: <amp-img src="../images/collection_images/collection1666.jpg" alt="Saints and Shady Ladies" width="100" height="100" layout = "responsive"></amp-img>

Note: 1667.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%

Winnie Ruth McKinnell was born 1905 in Darlington%comma% Indiana%comma% the daughter of a Methodist minister. At the age of 19%comma% she married Dr. William C. Judd%comma% a man 22 years her senior. The couple moved frequently looking for work. Their travels took them all over the United States and Mexico before they settled in Los Angeles%comma% California. In 1930%comma% Winnie Ruth left Los Angeles and her husband for the dryer air of Phoenix. On Friday night%comma% October 16%comma% 1931%comma% Winnie Ruth went to her friends' apartment for dinner and drinks. What happened next became an enduring and sensationalized part of history.

%newline%

Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%

This exhibit is dedicated to Dorothy Webb whose family has been interwoven with the Arizona ranching industry since before Statehood. Her husband%comma% Bud (Milton D.) Webb%comma% served as President of the Arizona Cattle Growers Association. In 1983%comma% after Richard Schaus' death%comma% Dorothy organized and identified the photographs%comma% and created the extensive finding aid for the Schaus Collection. Soon after%comma% she also arranged for the transfer of the Arizona Cattle Growers Association papers to the Foundation%comma% and has donated significant additions to this collection since then. For decades she has been a good friend and unwavering supporter of the Foundation's activities and an outstanding champion for the preservation of Arizona's history.

%newline%

%newline%

Note: 1669.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image) (Null image description)
Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%

The Mexican Heritage Project was a groundbreaking effort at the Arizona Historical Society to help preserve and tell a story which was in danger of being forgotten or marginalized -- the story of Tucson's Mexican-American community from the Gadsden Purchase until World War II. From 1979-1983%comma% a group of dedicated scholars%comma% field historians%comma% archivists%comma% librarians and community members united in an effort to gather photographs and oral histories directly from Tucson's Mexican-American community. The project's founders recognized the urgency and importance of such a project since it was clear that due to population influx and resultant growth%comma% Tucson was changing rapidly. As descendants of pioneer Mexican families aged%comma% their photographs%comma% documents%comma% traditions and memories were in real danger of being lost and remaining forever absent from the historical record of Arizona. During its approximately five years of active collecting%comma% the Mexican Heritage Project sought to address this by collecting over 4%comma%000 historical photographs directly from community members%comma% all of which were catalogued and added to the permanent collection of the Arizona Historical Society Library and Archives in Tucson.

%newline%

This assortment of images was selected to share a broad sampling of the images collected as part of the Mexican Heritage Project. These photographs portray a wide range of subjects%comma% including formal studio portraits of individuals and groups%comma% street scenes%comma% parades%comma% wedding portraits%comma% interiors%comma% ranch scenes%comma% musical groups%comma% workers%comma% theatrical productions%comma% school class photos%comma% and casual family snapshots.

%newline%

%newline%
Browse Link: %newline%Browse all records in

%newline%

This Arizona Memory Project online exhibit%comma% created in conjunction with Geronimo! Revered and Reviled (The Man Behind the Legend)%comma% features images of Geronimo%comma% other Apache leaders%comma% U.S. military leaders and the Apache scouts who worked for the U.S. Cavalry. Also included are rare C.S. Fly images from the 1886 Canon de los Embudos negotiations to end hostilities%comma% an event that saw Geronimo and Gen. George Crook sitting down face to face to parley. Finally%comma% the exhibit also shows scenes of Apache imprisonment and exile%comma% images of artifacts including Geronimo's rifle%comma% and a copy of Geronimo's signature and maps.

%newline%

Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library

Article Text:
%newline%

This Day In Arizona History charts some of the memorable moments in Arizona's history spanning the Territorial Days to the late 20th century. This Memory Project collection shows the breadth of history from the political to the personal%comma% noting the births and deaths of the famous and the infamous%comma% the building of key Arizona landmarks%comma% and the twists and turns of government%comma% the economy%comma% science and technology and society. The impact of Arizona's growth%comma% the Great Depression%comma% two World Wars and social revolutions in the mid-20th century can be seen throughout the collection. Also included are smaller (but just as telling) moments in history such as local dairy price wars%comma% the trial use of camels in the desert%comma% and Girl Scout cookie sales. The images corresponding to each day's event come from the more than 750%comma%000 images in the Arizona Historical Society's photographic collections.

%newline%

The Arizona Adjutants General exhibit is comprised of photographs of Adjutants General in Arizona from territorial days to the present. An Adjutant General is the highest ranking officer of a state's militia or National Guard when it is not called into federal service. When called to federal service by order of the President for deployment in foreign wars or to support large scale civil disturbances%comma% the Guard personnel are answerable to the federal military chain of command all the way up to the President.

Article Text:
%newline%

With the Civil War still going on and Carleton still fighting the Navajos%comma% the U.S. War Department authorized Governor John Noble Goodwin of Arizona to raise five companies of Arizona Volunteers in 1864. Recruitment was delayed for a year%comma% but by the fall of 1865%comma% the First Arizona Volunteer Infantry of more than 350 men had been issued into service under the command of nine officers. According to the Third Arizona Territorial Legislature%comma% the volunteers inflicted "greater punishment on the Apaches than all other troops in the territory." After their year in service ended%comma% the War Department disbanded the Arizona Volunteers because the army did not have the authority to retain native recruits. The 1st Volunteer Infantry began the lineage of the future "Bushmasters."

%newline%

As a result of Pancho Villa and his men crossing the Mexican border and raiding Columbus%comma% New Mexico%comma% General "Black Jack" Pershing was ordered to lead a "punitive expedition" to apprehend and capture Villa and his bandits. The President called up the militias of Arizona%comma% New Mexico and Texas on May 9%comma% 1916. The Arizona militia%comma% the First Arizona Infantry%comma% was mustered in by May 19. Three weeks after the passage of the 1916 National Defense Act in late June%comma% the National Guard of all of the states (except Nevada which did not have a militia)%comma% and Alaska and the District of Columbia were called into Federal service. There were as many as 111%comma%954 guardsmen along the border at the end of August 1916. Douglas%comma% Arizona%comma% was one of the four assembly points for the guard units. The Arizona National Guard was called into active federal service with Col. Alexander McKenzie Tuthill as regimental commander. Besides units stationed at Naco%comma% there were elements at Ajo%comma% Nogales%comma% Fort Huachuca%comma% Douglas and other border outposts.

%newline%

Arizona's First Infantry Regiment was drafted into Federal Service for World War I on August 5%comma% 1917%comma% as part of the 40th Division. The Regiment was re-designated as the 158th Infantry Regiment on October 3%comma% 1917%comma% and sent overseas in July and August 1918. In France%comma% the 158th Infantry was assigned to a division that furnished replacement personnel to other units. The 158th Infantry was honored to act as guard of honor to President Wilson during his residence in France in 1918%comma% and the 158th Infantry Band was chosen as Wilson's honor band.

%newline%

On September 16%comma% 1940%comma% with the declaration of National Emergency%comma% the 158th Infantry joined its parent organization%comma% the 45th Division%comma% at Ft. Sill%comma% Oklahoma. The troops trained for five months%comma% moving to Camp Barkley at Abilene%comma% Texas%comma% on February 28%comma% 1941. Following the December 7%comma% 1941%comma% attack on Pearl Harbor%comma% the 158th Infantry Regiment was removed from the 45th Division becoming a separate Regiment. January 1942 found the Regiment embarking at the Port of New Orleans and disembarking in the Panama Canal Zone.

%newline%

In Panama%comma% they trained in jungle warfare. Becoming famous for newly acquired jungle-fighting skills%comma% the Regiment took the name of the Bushmasters after the deadly bushmaster snake%comma% which became the distinguishing shoulder patch of the fighting 158th Regimental Combat Team. The name "Bushmasters" became well-known through the nation's press.

%newline%

General Douglas MacArthur personally requested that the Bushmasters be sent to his command in the Southwest Pacific Theater. They were on their way to Australia by January 2%comma% 1943%comma% landing two weeks later at Brisbane%comma% Queensland. When General Walter Krueger's headquarters moved to Milne Bay and on to Goodenough Island%comma% the 2nd Battalion%comma% 158th Infantry became the security force for his headquarters. On Christmas Day 1943%comma% Safford's Company G embarked for Arawe. It was there that the 158th Infantry had its "baptism of fire." A short time later the remainder of the 2nd Battalion arrived under command of LTC Frederick R. Stofft of Tucson%comma% Arizona. After the landing on Wakde-Sarmi in Dutch New Guinea they fought the Japanese 6th Tiger Marine Division from May 17 to June 12%comma% 1944. The Regiment traded 77 officers and men for 3000 of the enemy. They were relieved on 12 June by the 6th Infantry Division (which spoke well for the regiment as it took an entire division to replace them). With only a brief rest on the morning of 2 July%comma% the Regiment went ashore at Noemfoor with the mission to destroy the enemy and construct an airstrip that would handle B-29 bombers. Fifteen days later the mission was accomplished and General MacArthur landed on the newly constructed B-29 airdrome.

%newline%

It was at the battle at Lingayen Gulf%comma% where the Japanese invaded the Philippines 3 years earlier%comma% where Co G from Safford%comma% Arizona was awarded the Presidential Unit Citation for their action in capturing the 14-inch coast gun which was bringing heavy fire on the invasion force. By the end of the operation on January 27%comma% 100 Japanese field pieces had been captured or destroyed. General MacArthur "had returned."

%newline%

On April 1%comma% Easter Sunday 1945%comma% the 158th Infantry invaded the Bicol Peninsula in southern Luzon. The Regiment hit the Legaspi Port in a magnificent assault landing with naval landing craft.

%newline%

General MacArthur summarized about the Bushmasters: "No greater fighting combat team has ever deployed for battle." After being relieved by divisions in campaign after campaign across the Pacific%comma% the 158th Infantry was selected to spearhead the final invasion of Japan. The Bushmasters were under orders to proceed two days ahead of America's crushing D-Day%comma% to silence Japanese air warning stations south of Kyushu. Timely capitulation of Japan saved the 158th Infantry from what many believed would have been a certain suicide mission. On October 13%comma% 1945%comma% the 158th Infantry landed in Yokohama%comma% Japan. The great odyssey was over. FROM ARIZONA TO JAPAN - IN FIVE YEARS! Members were then shipped home and the 158th was deactivated at Utsunomiya%comma% Japan on January 17%comma% 1946.

%newline%

%newline%

Article Text:
%newline%The Arizona Military Museum%comma% an Arizona Centennial Legacy Project%comma% is operated by a Historical Society whose purposes are: "To enhance the appreciation of the military history of Arizona and the contributions of the Militia of Arizona and the Arizona National Guard to the State of Arizona and to the Nation…" and "…to discover and memorialize the history of the Military of Arizona%comma% the Arizona National Guard%comma% and the general military history of Arizona%comma% and to establish and maintain a museum on land leased%comma% owned%comma% or otherwise controlled by the Society." It also portrays events%comma% persons%comma% and other historical information relating to…the military service of Arizonans in wars and other military actions in Arizona and around the world. The Arizona Military Museum is an Army Museum Activity under Army and National Guard regulations. It is located within the "old Arsenal Building" which also houses the Arizona Regional Training Institute within the confines of the Papago Park Military Reservation. Descriptive text accompanying digital objects is a result of the research done by%comma% and conclusions of Joseph Abodeely%comma% President of the Arizona National Guard Historical Society and Director of the Arizona Military Museum.

%newline%

Note: 1679.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)

Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%

Attorney General Opinions (1892 to current%comma% in process) are issued when requested by either house of the State Legislature%comma% any public officer of the State%comma% or a county attorney%comma% on a question of law relating to their office. The Attorney General's office does not issue opinions for private citizens%comma% nor does it offer legal advice to private citizens.

%newline%

The first two digits of each opinion indicate the year the opinion was issued (I99 indicates the year the opinion was issued in 1999)%comma% and the next three digits indicate the order in which the opinion was issued. For example%comma% I99-003 is the third opinion issued in 1999. The number in parentheses (e.g.%comma% R98-025) refers to the year and request order for an opinion. Opinions and letters before 1937 are identified by a date (e.g.. 1892-JUL-31) rather than by opinion number. Certain opinions%comma% such as opinions ending with an "L" (e.g.%comma% 63-1-L) were written as "letter" opinions while opinions ending with "ESC" (e.g.%comma% 53-1-ESC) were written to the Employment Security Commission.

%newline%

Legal custody of pre-1937 Attorney General Opinions resides with History and Archives of Arizona State Library%comma% Archives and Public Records. Legal custody of Attorney General Opinions from 1937 to the present resides with the Attorney General's office. Opinions and letters from 1937-1998 were microfilmed in the condition they were received from the Attorney General's Office and saved in PDF format by Records Management of Arizona State Library Archives and Public Records. Attorney General Opinions from 1999 to present were downloaded from the Attorney General's office website. Attorney General's opinion from 2005 to present may be found on the Attorney General's website. Opinions found prior to 2005 may be found in this collection. Opinions of the Attorney General are advisory only.

%newline%

Federal publications are printed by the authority of Congress or by executive or judicial agencies at taxpayer expense and are distributed to federal agencies%comma% their clientele%comma% and to depository libraries which serve the public. The Arizona State Library%comma% Archives and Public Records' Law and Research Division is the Regional Federal Depository Library for Arizona designated to receive U.S. Government Printing Office (GPO) publications distributed through the Federal Depository Library Program. This collection includes notable statistics%comma% research%comma% and reports issued by the GPO on all aspects of the state as well as federal "fugitive documents" featuring Arizona. Ultimately%comma% the Arizona-Related Federal Publications collection will be a comprehensive resource for publications relating to Arizona and her people issued in digital form by the federal government.
