Note: 1690.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%

On January 20%comma% 1988%comma% the Arizona House of Representatives began hearings on Governor Evan Mecham's alleged illegal activities and on February 8 voted to impeach him. The impeachment trial commenced in the Arizona State Senate%comma% with the Senate acting as the Court of Impeachment%comma% on February 29%comma% 1988%comma% and ended on April 8 with Mecham's conviction and subsequent impeachment for obstruction of justice and misuse of government funds. The Senate failed to muster the votes necessary to bar the ex-governor from holding elected office in the future%comma% and thus the next several years saw his failed attempts to retake the governorship and win a U.S. Senate seat.

%newline%

There are approximately 5%comma%450 pages of transcripts combined into 26 volumes/PDFs representing each of the 26 days of the hearings. Video of the hearings was originally captured on 2" Quadruplex video tapes by KAET. The original tapes were transferred to U-matic tapes and then to VHS tapes. KAET transferred the original Quadruplex tapes%comma% 1 set of U-matic tapes%comma% and two sets of the VHS tapes to the Arizona State Library%comma% Archives and Public Records. Digital copies of the U-matic tapes were created in 2011 by the Arizona State Archives for preservation and continued access. Due to licensing agreement with KAET and other members of the Broadcast Pool Committee%comma% the digital videos are available for viewing at the Arizona State Archives by request only.

%newline%

%newline%

Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%

From 1946 to 1960%comma% in the remote pine country of east-central Arizona%comma% the University of Arizona's Department of Anthropology%comma% under the direction of Dr. Emil W. Haury%comma% operated one of the first archaeological field schools in the nation where hundreds of students were trained in archaeological field work. The school was called the Point of Pines Field School because it was situated and surrounded by significant Mogollon pueblo ruins%comma% the largest being Point of Pines Pueblo. This collection of 39 images from the Arizona State Museum's Photograph Collection documents the daily life of the camp and the early archaeological processes used in their site excavations. Most of the photos presented here were taken during the 1946-1956 period.

%newline%

%newline%

Note: 1692.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%This exhibit of twenty-seven Forman Hanna photographs from the Arizona State Museum's collection showcases the tradition of pictorial photography as practiced in the early twentieth century by photographers in the American West. Native Americans%comma% cowboys and scenic landscapes were some of Forman Hanna's favorite subjects.

%newline%Hanna came to Arizona in 1904 and through a friend found a position as a pharmacist in Globe%comma% Arizona. Globe's proximity to the native people and landscapes that Hanna wanted to photograph kept him there for the remainder of his life%comma% although he traveled widely in Arizona%comma% New Mexico%comma% Utah and Texas.

%newline%Hanna's photographs of Apache%comma% Navajo%comma% Hopi and Acoma Indians%comma% as presented here%comma% are set in their villages and surroundings and document their ways of life and the native architecture of the early to mid 1900s. Many of his photographs of native peoples were candid shots where he sought to capture aspects of quotidian Native American life. This demonstrates his desire to preserve the way of life of these Native peoples as well as how interesting he found their lifestyles.

%newline%Hanna also documented the cowboy lifestyle%comma% as he feared it would soon disappear altogether. Cattle drives%comma% horsemanship and the picturesque attire of the cowboys were aspects of the cowboy of the early 20th century that Hanna strived to preserve through his photographs.

%newline%Hanna found the landscape of the Southwest fascinating. Unique rock formations made by wind and water erosion%comma% canyon walls and desert vegetation were transformed into people and human-made objects though Hanna's lens. For Hanna%comma% photography was a means of sharing the wonders of the people and landscape around him. He wanted those who viewed his photographs to share in the pleasure he felt when he took them.

%newline%At one stage in his life Hanna photographed nudes in a small canyon near Globe. His subjects were local girls and women ranging from 5 to 25 years old. He was surprised by how professional they were as models%comma% holding any pose he requested for extended periods of time.

%newline%Hanna's photographs are in numerous museum collections in the United States%comma% including the Brooklyn Museum%comma% the Chicago Museum of Science and Industry%comma% the Los Angeles Museum%comma% and the Smithsonian Institution. Photographs at the Arizona State Museum were generously donated by the late Mrs. Josephine Hanna.

%newline%

%newline%

On June 2 through 6%comma% 1980%comma% Helga Teiwes visited Hickiwan Village%comma% Tohono O'odham Indian Reservation%comma% Arizona. The process was documented from the gathering of supplies for the actual pot to the gathering of the materials for the creation of the paint. The polychrome pots that were created were donated to the Arizona State Museum.

Note: 1694.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%

The Medallion Papers is a series of 39 publications issued between 1928-1950 by the Gila Pueblo Archaeological Foundation. Gila Pueblo%comma% as it later became known%comma% was one of the earliest Arizona institutions doing archaeological surveying and research in the Southwest. It was founded by Winifred and Harold S. Gladwin as a private foundation and employed professional archaeologists whose research was published in the Medallion Papers. Their work was instrumental in defining the Hohokam%comma% Mogollon%comma% San Simon and Cochise cultures and in describing early pottery types including Hohokam red-on-buff%comma% Salado polychrome%comma% Casas Grandes and others.

%newline%

Gila Pueblo was located in east-central Arizona%comma% several miles south of Globe%comma% Arizona. It was in operation until 1950%comma% at which time the Foundation was dissolved. The buildings were acquired by the National Park Service and became the Southwest Archaeological Center from 1950 to 1971. They are now occupied by the Gila Community College (formally the Globe Campus/Eastern Arizona College). The Foundation's artifacts%comma% photographs%comma% library and documents were donated to the Arizona State Museum%comma% University of Arizona.

%newline%

Distinguished archaeologists published in the Medallion Papers include Charles Avery Amsden%comma% Ernst Antevs%comma% Alice M. Brues%comma% Nora Gladwin%comma% Winifred and Harold Gladwin%comma% Emil W. Haury%comma% Fred Hawley%comma% M. M. Leighton%comma% Deric O'Bryan%comma% E. B. Sayles%comma% George C. Vaillant%comma% and George and Edna Woodbury.

%newline%

The Medallion Papers are digitally presented in the Arizona Memory Project in their full text. The original issues Nos. 1-3 carry the imprint "Privately printed for the Medallion%comma% Pasadena%comma% California%comma%" while issues Nos. 4-39 have the imprint "Gila Pueblo%comma% Globe%comma% Arizona." The earliest issues were not published with authors or numbering and it wasn't until they became more widely distributed that adhesive labels were prepared with this information. All print work was done by Lancaster Press%comma% Inc.%comma% Lancaster%comma% Pennsylvania. Each volume was beautifully crafted on heavy cream-colored paper stock and most issues included color plates and line art. Covers displayed a design taken from a Querino polychrome bowl as the Medallion Papers colophon. The original format was 6 5/8 by 9 3/ 4 inches until issue No. 25%comma% at which time the format changed to 8 1/2 by 11 1/8 inches. Issue No. 25%comma% Excavations at Snaketown: Material Culture%comma% which was originally printed in 1937%comma% was later reprinted in 1965 by the University of Arizona Press%comma% which retains its distribution rights.

%newline%

Also presented here are the Amsden Pottery Paintings%comma% a collection of 18 oil paintings commissioned by the Gila Pueblo Archaeological Foundation for use as illustrations in the Medallion Papers. The paintings were executed by Theodore ("Ted") Price Amsden between 1929 and 1936. The images of the paintings are presented in the order in which they appear in the Medallion Papers.

%newline%

%newline%

%newline%

The A.P. Miller Photograph Collection was donated to the Arizona State Museum by Dr. Lorraine M. Sherer in 1979. A.P. Miller%comma% a railroad engineer from Needles%comma% CA%comma% was also an avid photographer whose favorite subjects included the Mojave Desert%comma% locomotives%comma% and the Hualapai and Mojave peoples. This selection of 25 photographs of locomotives was taken in California from 1938-1942. A.P. Miller died in 1944.

%newline%

Note: 1696.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%

Rosamond Spicer (1913-1999) received a bachelor's degree in archaeology from Northwestern University in 1934 and a Master's degree in anthropology from the University of Chicago in 1938. She lived on the Tohono O'odham Reservation%comma% previously known as the Papago Reservation%comma% from October%comma% 1942%comma% to July%comma% 1943. The photos were taken as part of the Bureau of Indian Affairs (BIA) and the University of Chicago Committee on Human Development Indian Education and Research Project. The results of this project were discussed in The Desert People%comma% written by Spicer%comma% Alice Joseph%comma% and Jane Chesky.

%newline%

The majority of the photos were taken by Rosamond in Topawa%comma% Arizona%comma% where Rosamond lived in the Feast House with her young son Barry. The photos are a mix of representations of everyday life on the reservation and special events such as Rodeo and religious processions. Descriptions of the photos come from an index typed up by Rosamond Spicer in 1994%comma% information she wrote on the back of prints%comma% and from Tohono O'odham members. Most dates%comma% photographers%comma% and names of subjects are listed%comma% but some are unknown. In addition to her time spent on the reservation in the early 1940s%comma% Spicer visited again in the 1950s and 1960s%comma% and continued to gather photos of the Tohono O'odham taken by others.

%newline%

According to The Desert People%comma% the Tohono O'odham reservation held about 5%comma%900 residents at the time of the study. Populations ranged from anywhere to 1%comma%200 in the Sells district to 250 in the Gu Vo district. An additional 200 lived in the Gila Bend reservation%comma% and almost 500 at the San Xavier reservation. The remaining of the almost 7%comma%000 strong population lived off-reservation. At the time Rosamond was living on the reservation%comma% many families still worked as farmers and ranchers%comma% and two villages still migrated annually from the fields to the foothills. However%comma% more and more were finding off reservation work in mines or on nearby farms%comma% or they found government employment. Most followed Roman or Sonoran Catholicism%comma% but the Presbyterian Church had a strong following as well. Schools were typically run by the BIA or Catholics. However%comma% there were no secondary schools on the reservation. Only government or Catholic boarding schools off reservation were available for higher education. English was taught in schools%comma% but it was not the predominate language on the reservation at this point%comma% with only a third of adults able to speak it. Sells%comma% as now%comma% was the seat of the government in the early 1940s. The tribal council was in charge of arts and crafts%comma% the tribal fair and rodeo%comma% loans%comma% the tribal herd%comma% and administering tribal law. However%comma% at this time the Tohono O'odham still were not allowed to vote%comma% and they did not own the rights to the minerals under their land.

%newline%

Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%This collection highlights select images from the Gila River Akimel O'odham%comma% San Carlos Apache%comma% and White Mountain Apache basket making process%comma% as photographed by Helga Teiwes.

%newline%On April 12%comma% 1973%comma% Helga Teiwes visited the Gila River Indian Reservation%comma% near Bapchule%comma% Arizona%comma% to document Julia Francisco's basket making processes. She photographed the gathering%comma% cleaning%comma% drying%comma% and stripping of basket making supplies%comma% such as willow%comma% devil's claw%comma% and martynia%comma% as well as the creation of a woven basket depicting a squash blossom design. Helga later returned on August 17%comma% 1973%comma% to observe the Cattail Harvest at Stanfield Ditch%comma% where she documented Julia Francisco cutting and collecting cattail%comma% a plant commonly used in her basket making.

%newline%In May 1984%comma% Helga photographed various basket making processes of the Apache culture of Whiteriver and San Carlos. During this trip%comma% she photographed the gathering locations where common plant materials are collected for use in basket making. She also documented Joanna Taylor cutting and collecting willow for use in basket weaving and Viola Taylor preparing materials and intricately weaving willow baskets.

%newline%On the same trip%comma% she highlighted the basketry of Cecilia Henry from Peridot%comma% Arizona and Minnie Narcisco%comma% from Cibecue%comma% Arizona%comma% who proudly display their burden baskets.

%newline%

Arizona State University's early research scientists were scholarly pioneers of earth%comma% ice%comma% animal%comma% mineral%comma% and space. In Arizona State's first days of transformation from a small college to a true university%comma% these scientists were already leaders in their fields%comma% asking tough questions and seeking elusive answers. Their work at ASU helped others to understand venomous animals%comma% meteorites%comma% genetics%comma% rare earth oxides%comma% frozen deserts%comma% and local geology.

%newline%

This exhibit was developed from the University Archives of Arizona State University Libraries. It features the documents%comma% notebooks%comma% images%comma% specimens%comma% and equipment of ASU researchers including Dr. Herb Stahnke of the Department of Biology%comma% Dr. Carleton Moore and H. H. Nininger of the Center for Meteorite Studies%comma% Dr. Charles Woolf of the Zoology Department%comma% Dr. LeRoy Eyring of the Eyring Center for Solid State Science%comma% and Dr. Troy Péwé of the Department of Geology.

This collection presents a brief introduction to the rock art of Cochise County%comma% Arizona. A wide diversity of prehistoric and historic rock art is found in the county including petroglyphs and pictographs. Petroglyphs are carved rock designs and pictographs are painted rock designs. Rock art is much more than meaningless sketches. It is a visual record from the past of various concepts%comma% such as ceremony%comma% religion%comma% life style and art. Five different cultures are represented in the collection images; Apache%comma% Hohokam%comma% Mimbres and Mogollon. Rock art is being threatened by natural deterioration%comma% vandalism and development. This collection is Cochise College Libraries effort toward its preservation.

%newline%

In May of 1881%comma% just three months after Cochise County was formed out of southeastern Pima County%comma% district court sessions began in Tombstone%comma% Arizona. The County Treasurer plays a crucial role in county government administration.

This collection of photos depicts the work and lives of the men of the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) at Colossal Cave in Vail%comma% AZ%comma% 1934-1937. The CCC was a federal government program designed to conserve our country's natural resources and to provide jobs and training to young%comma% unmarried men. The men of the CCC made improvements inside Colossal Cave%comma% constructed buildings%comma% and built picnic areas under the supervision of State Park Service personnel. They lived in a camp supervised by U.S. Army personnel%comma% where they engaged in educational%comma% sports%comma% and recreational activities.

Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%

The Hedgpeth Hills face east%comma% towards the rising sun. At one time%comma% the hills were next to a flowing creek that supported communities of people%comma% plants and animals. Archaic%comma% Hohokam%comma% and Patayan peoples passed through the area and left their mark by pecking over 1%comma%500 symbols into the basalt boulders. We do not know the reason they left the petroglyphs%comma% or what story the markings tell. However%comma% we do know that each generation plays a role in changing the land by communicating their traditions. Today%comma% the Deer Valley Rock Art Center protects the Hedgpeth Hills petroglyph site and offers an opportunity for interpretation and appreciation of cultural expressions.

%newline%

%newline%

In the early 1960s%comma% ten young Asian-American women joined together to develop friendships and organized to provide community service as the Desert Jade Junior Woman's Club in Phoenix%comma% Arizona. Within a year%comma% club membership grew to 20. Today%comma% with removal of the age limitation of 35 years for junior club membership%comma% the group is known as the GFWC Desert Jade Woman' s Club. The many philanthropic and civic projects of the group have included donations of time%comma% money%comma% and energy to various local fire departments%comma% veteran's groups%comma% community%comma% service%comma% and family organizations. The Phoenix Art Museum as well as St. Vincent De Paul are just two of the many organizations who have benefitted from the club's efforts. From its inception%comma% members of the Desert Jade Woman's Club have felt the need to give back to the community in which they lived. This collection represents barely a glimpse of the past 50 years in which the club has played its part in the history of the state of Arizona.

%newline%

The Phoenix Girl Scouts were formed into the Maricopa Girl Scout Council in 1936. By 1968%comma% the 50th Anniversary of Girl Scouting in Arizona%comma% the Maricopa Girl Scout Council had grown into the Arizona Cactus-Pine Council (GS - ACPC) and covered the northern 2/3 of the state. In 1988%comma% Dorothy Canfield Foster compiled a history of the GS - ACPC%comma% relying on the artifacts and memory of Jean Clark%comma% leader of Girl Scout Troop 1 for 50 years. Barbara Anderson%comma% a Council staff member%comma% was inspired by this history and later used it as a foundation for creating the Historical Society after her retirement in 1985.

Article Text:
%newline%

Old Morenci and Metcalf mining townsites were located on the eastern border of Arizona from 1870 - 1984. Morenci was known as "Joy Camp"%comma% (named after Captain Miles Joy). In 1882%comma% "Joy Camp" was renamed "Morenci" by William Church%comma% head of the Detroit Copper Company. Metcalf was named after Robert and James Metcalf%comma% two pioneer copper miners. Through 1932 all mining was underground. Open pit mining began in 1937. The town was completely gone by 1983. New Morenci is now located where Plantsite was situated. Both old Morenci and Metcalf are now completely engulfed by the open pit.

Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%

This collection is a collaboration between Jerome Historical Society and the Postal History Foundation. It includes photographs%comma% postal documents%comma% postcards%comma% postmarks%comma% and covers or cachets%comma% which are envelopes with special illustrations on them. Like many other towns in Arizona%comma% the postal history of Jerome closely reflects the boom and bust of the mining industry. As the mining operations grew and the population soared%comma% the post office also was established and expanded. Later%comma% as fires swept through the town on multiple occasions%comma% the post office also suffered. Then when the use of dynamite increased%comma% the entire town began to shift and the post office collapsed in slides that affected much of the town. But the post office also demonstrated the strength of the community. In the 1970s when it was threatened with closure%comma% a group of citizens gathered to protest. Although the population had dwindled to a handful at that point%comma% the inhabitants recognized that their survival as a town was closely linked to the survival of the post office. At its height%comma% the population of Jerome was close to 15%comma%000 and today it is 400 (with an annual visitation reportedly at close to one million people).

%newline%

Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%

Forrest's original photograph collection is comprised of over 8%comma%000 unique images dating from 1898-1968. Each image is thoroughly detailed with rich descriptions that provide specific locations%comma% individuals%comma% dates%comma% and contextual information - a rarity for most Archivists working with photographic collections. Forrest provided all the descriptions%comma% switching between a first and third-person narrative voice as appropriate. As part of the selection process for putting this collection online%comma% Museum of Northern Arizona staff and volunteers selected images that were taken in the northern portion of the state of Arizona%comma% specifically the Arizona portion of the Colorado Plateau. From this selection and in consultation with appropriate liaisons within the Hopi community%comma% images deemed to be culturally-sensitive (ceremonial dances etc.) were excluded. Of the 2112 images taken by Forrest that are at the Museum of Northern Arizona%comma% 541 were selected using the afore-mentioned criteria.

%newline%

%newline%

Works of art were collected by Museum staff during regular collecting trips to the Hopi villages%comma% a practice which continues today. Much like in the past%comma% current festival organizers visit with individual artists and encourage submitting both utilitarian and artistic pieces (ceramics%comma% basketry%comma% katsinas%comma% textiles%comma% jewelry) for judging and potential consignment sales. Artists and demonstrators are also invited to sell and demonstrate their work directly for Museum visitors during the festival. Today's Hopi festival - the Hopi Festival of Arts & Crafts - has undergone some changes since its first incarnation%comma% but the goal of bringing increased awareness of Hopi culture through its arts and crafts remains its core intent.

The Montezuma Castle Historic Photo Archive collection represents the history of Montezuma Castle National Monument%comma% from its time before National Park Service control in the late nineteenth century%comma% through the 1960's. These images chronicle not only early interest and exploration of the site%comma% but also document efforts by the National Park Service to preserve and stabilize these prehistoric structures for the benefit of future generations. Having just celebrated its 100th anniversary as a National Monument in December of 2006%comma% the National Park Service is pleased to present these images to the public. Montezuma Castle cliff dwelling was recently named one of the top seven man-made wonders in Arizona and stands as one of the best preserved cliff dwellings in North America.

The Day Family were Anglo traders%comma% on the Navajo Reservation in eastern Arizona. The collection includes the personal and business papers of Sam Day%comma% Sr. (1845-1925) surveyor%comma% Indian trader%comma% legislator and United States Indian Commissioner; Anna Day%comma% Sam Sr.'s wife (1872-1932); and of their children%comma% Charles L. Day (1879-1918)%comma% Samuel Day%comma% Jr. (1889-1944)%comma% United States deputy Marshall. The collection contains archaeological reports%comma% Navajo land boundary maps and notes%comma% business records%comma% as well as several documents pertaining to Navajo culture%comma% including a copy of the treaty between the U.S. Government and the Navajo nation. The Day Family Records are particularly rich in chronicling early Anglo and Navajo relations.

Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%

Fred Harvey saw a need for better food and service along the rails and in 1876 pioneered a chain of restaurants and inns known as Harvey Houses from Chicago to San Francisco. Experience soon demonstrated that women made better servers%comma% and the 'Harvey Girls' were borne. Newspaper ads read: "Wanted: Young women 18 to 30 years of age%comma% of good moral character%comma% attractive and intelligent%comma% as waitresses in Harvey Eating Houses on the Santa Fe in the West." Fred Harvey was one of the first to employ women in great numbers. Winslow's first Harvey House built in 1897 made a welcome haven for travelers%comma% as the restored second Harvey House%comma% the La Posada%comma% does today. This exhibit offers a glimpse of both to showcase just where these Girls worked%comma% pictures them in and out of uniform%comma% and includes some interesting memorabilia.

%newline%

%newline%

Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%

This collection offers snapshots%comma% some over 100 years old%comma% from Native American life in and around Winslow%comma% AZ%comma% a border town to the Navajo and Hopi Reservations. These two tribes comprise most of the native population near here%comma% but Winslow became a second home to a contingent of Laguna Indians and members of various other tribes. The Navajos are known as weavers and silversmiths%comma% the Hopis as basket makers%comma% kachina carvers%comma% and for the storied ceremonies the latter represents. Both tribes have survived in a land and climate that can be inhospitable and formidable at best. For well over one hundred years their works have been prized collections and are representations of ancient cultures still embedded in the hearts%comma% hands and traditions of artisans of today.

%newline%

%newline%

Continuing on a prehistoric note is the large Mary Clark Collection of Anasazi pottery and implements%comma% excavated in the early 1900's. All of the items represented in this online collection are on display in the Museum.

Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%

Trading posts were not just a western phonenoma%comma% as Congress established Federal Trading Houses at the urging of George Washington in 1796. By the time posts were dotting the landscape in northern Arizona%comma% laws had changed several times%comma% but traders were still required to register in those early years. The landscape changed somewhat from post to post but constant was the isolation surrounding each site. It required stalwart pioneers to undertake a business such as this%comma% moving their families into harsh environments. Yet a look at these photographs belies the severity of daily life. You will see a range of emotions on faces that could have well been in more civilized locales.

%newline%

%newline%

This collection is a collaboration between Oracle Historical Society and the Postal History Foundation . It includes photographs%comma% postal documents%comma% postcards%comma% postmarks%comma% and covers or cachets%comma% which are envelopes with special illustrations on them. There were a number of different post office locations in the Oracle area during the territorial period%comma% including the American Flag Ranch%comma% Acadia Ranch%comma% and the Mercantile Store. The history of the town of Oracle is%comma% like many other towns in Arizona%comma% deeply intertwined with mining and ranching. As the population grew%comma% post offices would open%comma% and as mines closed and people moved away%comma% the post offices would also close. Because postal history cannot be separated from human history%comma% the items in this collection reflect various aspects of daily life from the Territorial period to recent years%comma% including settlement and ranch life.

The Sonoran Heritage Collection contains resources and documents developed by the Tucson Public Library%comma% in conjunction with local institutions and organizations%comma% with the intent to educate the public about the history%comma% culture%comma% and peoples of the Sonoran Desert region of Arizona and Mexico. The materials in this collection were released in packets dedicated to specific topics%comma% including "Clothes and Costumes%comma%" "Play%comma%" "Power%comma%" "Shelter%comma%" "Family%comma%" "Work%comma%" "Genius%comma%" and "Destiny." The topics of these packets were defined%comma% examined%comma% and expounded upon through articles%comma% stories and exercises for the purpose of developing a new perspective on the history and values of the Sonoran Desert region. These learning packets were augmented by lectures and public events held in the various branches of the Tucson Public Library from January 1978 to December 1980.

The Connell Collection of Historic Maricopa Pottery consists of pots that were collected by Eliza Ann Connell and her daughter%comma% Caroline%comma% between 1895 and 1907%comma% in Phoenix. According to documents on file at both Pueblo Grande Museum and the Arizona State Museum%comma% Burridge D. Butler purchased the collection from Caroline Connell Smurthwaite for $500%comma% at the urging of Emil Haury%comma% on behalf of the Arizona State Museum in Tucson. The collection was given to the ASM%comma% where it was cataloged%comma% and%comma% at the request of the donor%comma% 173 pieces were transferred to Pueblo Grande Museum in Phoenix. The stated intent of the donor was to have at least part of the collection close to where Maricopa people currently reside. The Connell Collection forms the core of Pueblo Grande's Maricopa pottery collection.

%newline%

Note: 1753.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%

Pueblo Grande was a major Hohokam village on the north bank of the Salt River in what is now Phoenix%comma% Arizona. Pueblo Grande was occupied for 1000 years%comma% from about AD 500 - 1450. In addition to dwellings%comma% it contained public architecture%comma% such as the platform mound%comma% a stone reinforced adobe structure the size of a football field%comma% and a multi-storey adobe "big house" like the one at Casa Grande Ruins National Monument. The Hohokam were desert farmers who practiced irrigation agriculture%comma% and who collaboratively created a sophisticated and far-reaching canal system to bring water from the Salt River to their fields in the valley. In addition to food crops%comma% they grew cotton and may have had a monopoly on its production for several centuries. As artists%comma% they are best known for making shell jewelry and distinctive red-on-buff pottery.

%newline%

%newline%

The William P. Jones collection is a small series letters dating from 1860 to 1867. He was born to Porter Jones and Elizabeth Jenkins Pendleton in 1837%comma% and was listed in the Arizona census of 1864. As a young man%comma% Jones traveled first to Virginia%comma% California%comma% then to Aurora%comma% Nevada Territory%comma% and finally to the Hassayampa%comma% Arizona Territory%comma% where he worked in the mining industry. The letters home to his family in the east detail Jones' travels%comma% work%comma% and day-to-day existence. Jones' letters to his family end in 1864%comma% and are picked up in 1866 by J.T. Alsap (a member of the Masons with William P. Jones)%comma% informing Mr. and Mrs. Porter Jones that their son was killed in a conflict with local Native Americans. Jones passed away at the age of 27%comma% and is buried in plot 56 at the Masonic Cemetery in Prescott.

%newline%

%newline%

LaVerne Harrell Clark%comma% the first director of the University of Arizona Poetry Center%comma% was also a writer of fiction and nonfiction%comma% an expert on Southwestern folklore and mythology%comma% and an accomplished photographer. During her tenure%comma% and for many years after her retirement%comma% Clark created photographic portraits of the poets who read at the Poetry Center. She photographed many of the great writers of the twentieth century%comma% including W.S. Merwin%comma% Donald Justice%comma% Leslie Marmon Silko%comma% Lucille Clifton%comma% and Alice Walker. Her photos are characterized by their natural%comma% unstudied quality: Clark was particularly gifted in capturing her subjects at their most expressive moments%comma% revealing the personalities behind the poems.

%newline%

%newline%

Article Text:
%newline%

Throughout the 1960s and 1970s%comma% University of Arizona visual art students collaborated with the Poetry Center to create silkscreen publicity posters for Poetry Center readings. Former Poetry Center Director Richard Shelton initiated a student competition to produce designs for these posters; the winning design for each reading was selected by the Poetry Center staff%comma% produced by a professional lithographer%comma% and distributed widely. The resulting posters are colorful%comma% exuberant%comma% and frequently emblematic of the times. Designs range from an op art-inspired poster for Lawrence Ferlinghetti to a poster incorporating the red sun of the Japanese national flag for a reading by Gary Snyder (who spent a number of years in Japan). The posters present a stunning array of famous names from the period%comma% including Ferlinghetti%comma% Snyder%comma% Ai%comma% James Tate%comma% and Elizabeth Bishop.

%newline%

%newline%

This collection of photographs%comma% documents%comma% postal covers and oral histories tells the story of Vail%comma% Arizona. It is often called the "Town Between the Tracks" because of its location between the east and west bound tracks of first%comma% the Southern Pacific Railroad%comma% and later the Union Pacific. Since 1908 the adobe post office has been a focal point for government%comma% communication and commerce in Vail and the surrounding region. All other traces of Vail's railroad%comma% mining and ranching roots are gone%comma% erased by time%comma% population growth%comma% and development. The post office characterizes the connections between the economic and cultural forces that converged at Vail in the late 19th and early 20th century.

%newline%

%newline%

Title: Beat Poetry%comma% Broadsides%comma% and Little Magazines
Publisher: Published by Utah State University - Merrill-Cazier Library
Article Text:
%newline%

Beat Movement broadsides and posters in this collection were part of a revolution in self-publishing as artists and poets seized control over the dissemination of their work and took it directly to the people and the streets%comma% dodging the strong forces of censorship that permeated 1950s America. Diverse in size%comma% quality%comma% and quantity – from mimeographs to fine letterpress print – broadsides have been important vehicles for political%comma% social%comma% and cultural commentary on a profusion of subjects including politics%comma% free love%comma% the anti-war movement%comma% environmental consciousness%comma% civil rights%comma% free speech%comma% and more. The broadsides are critical primary research materials%comma% artfully documenting the dynamic social movements of the 1950s and 1960s.

%newline%
AMP Image Version: <amp-img src="../images/collection_images/collection1785.jpg" alt="Broadsides" width="370" height="207" layout = "responsive"></amp-img>
Browse Link: %newline%Browse all records in Beat Poetry%comma% Broadsides%comma% and Little Magazines

Title: Collecting Memories: Oral Histories of American Folklorists
Publisher: Published by Utah State University - Merrill-Cazier Library
Article Text:
%newline%

Collecting Memories features the voices of American folklorists and aims to document the development and change in the field of folklore since the mid-twentieth century. A joint project of the American Folklore Society (AFS) and Utah State University (USU) (official repository of the AFS archives)%comma% this collection offers a descriptive listing of interviews held at USU and at other institutions. The USU interviews include transcript%comma% sound%comma% photographs and more. Interviews housed at other institutions are mostly analog and not available online; however%comma% links lead users to descriptive records at the owning institutions where in some cases transcripts are available.

Three generations of Comptons operated the Compton Studio%comma% creating a remarkable visual record of business%comma% agriculture%comma% education%comma% and social activities in Box Elder County spanning almost century.

Title: Forest Ranger Daybooks of Aaron P. Christiansen
Publisher: Published by Utah State University - Merrill-Cazier Library
Article Text:
%newline%

The fifteen daybooks in this collection describe the daily activities of a Forest Service Ranger in the early twentieth century. Written by Aaron Parley Christiansen when he was assistant Forest Ranger for the Uintah Forest%comma% the daybooks cover 1915-1921 and describe his work activities in both the field and the office. Working in the Uintah National Forest%comma% Christiansen was required to keep a daily log of his activities; these books represent that record. Subjects mentioned include timber sales%comma% grazing leases%comma% road building%comma% forest fires and reseeding projects. Christiansen spent a great deal of his time in the field primarily working out of the Salt Creek Ranger Station; many of the entries concern the Salt Creek area. Of particular interest are the comments concerning Forest Service philosophy and Christiansen's philosophy about conservation.

%newline%

Image Description: Aaron P. Christiansen Daybook 6%comma% November%comma% 1916 and January%comma% 1917

Title: Logan Canyon Reflections
Publisher: Published by Utah State University - Merrill-Cazier Library
Article Text:
%newline%

Listen to people who have worked or played in Logan Canyon during the last century talk about what the canyon has meant to them. Ranchers%comma% scientists%comma% activists%comma% scholars%comma% foresters%comma% sheepherders%comma% hikers%comma% fishermen%comma% and nearby residents tell their canyon stories%comma% adding a social and cultural perspective to scientific studies of Logan Canyon. Interviews with key land managers and users of Logan Canyon originate from the Logan Canyon Land Use Management Oral Histories project (2008-2009). The project's three partners were: Utah State University's Merrill-Cazier Library%comma% College of Natural Resources%comma% and Maintain West Center for Regional Studies. Generous funding came from the LIbrary's Special Collections and Archives%comma% the Mountain West Center%comma% the Utah Humanities Council%comma% and the Utah Division of State History.

%newline%

Title: Western Photographers
Publisher: Published by Utah State University - Merrill-Cazier Library
Article Text:
%newline%

In the 1860s and 1870s the Intermountain West for most Easterners was an exotic%comma% interesting%comma% and potentially dangerous place. Eager to see images%comma% but distrusting the accuracy of artists%comma% they clamored for the realism that photography could provide. William Henry Jackson%comma% A.J. Russell%comma% C.R. Savage%comma% Jack Hillers%comma% Carleton Watkins%comma% and others used the transcontinental railroad to transport the bulky equipment needed for collodion%comma% wet-plate negatives that brought top dollar in the form of stereo-views or "large-format" prints. The twenty years from 1860 to 1880 was the golden age of Western photography because quality images were in high demand. Every government survey and all the major railroads had official photographers. Interest would wane%comma% however%comma% in the 1880s as the general public started to want cheap%comma% low quality shots of popular tourist destinations. Furthermore%comma% as the West became mundane%comma% the more evocative%comma% romantic recreations of the "Old West" found in dime novels and Wild West shows became more popular.

%newline%
AMP Image Version: <amp-img src="../images/collection_images/collection1792.jpg" alt="Grand Canyon" width="343" height="236" layout = "responsive"></amp-img>
Browse Link: %newline%Browse all records in Western Photographers

Title: Frances Winton Champ Music Collection
Publisher: Published by Utah State University - Merrill-Cazier Library
Article Text:
%newline%

Frances Winton Champ lived and breathed music. A resident of Cache Valley%comma% Utah%comma% this accomplished pianist performed as a solist with the Boston%comma% Chicago%comma% and Utah Symphonies; she also composed and taught music. Serving as a musical snapshot of Cache Valley history%comma% this collection includes not only popular music anthologies and sheet music%comma% but also numerous printed programs detailing Champ's piano recitals and performances as well as cultural artifacts offering a glimpse into the rich artistic life of Logan during the late 1920s through the 1940s. Many of the vintage scores are beautifully printed with several important music publishers in both Europe and the United States represented. Some handwritten pieces are illustrated by former USU professor and artist Everett Thorpe. One%comma% published for the beginning piano student%comma% uses themes from Western Native American culture.

%newline%

Image Description: Franz Liszt : 3 Etudes de Concert : Piano Solo
Browse Link: %newline%Browse all records in Frances Winton Champ Music Collection

Title: Civilian Conservation Corps in Idaho
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%

The Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) was a public works relief program that operated from 1933 to 1942 in the United States for unemployed%comma% unmarried men from relief families%comma% ages 17 to 23. A part of the New Deal of President Franklin D. Roosevelt%comma% it provided unskilled manual labor jobs related to the conservation and development of natural resources in rural lands owned by federal%comma% state and local governments. The CCC was designed to provide employment for young men in relief families who had difficulty finding jobs during the Great Depression while at the same time implementing a general natural resource conservation program in every state and territory. Maximum enrollment at any one time was 300%comma%000; in nine years 2.5 million young men participated.

%newline%

Image Description: Logging at Camp Brown Creek%comma% Idaho%comma% 1930s

Title: Leo J. 'Scoop' Leeburn Photographs
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%

Leo “Scoop” Leeburn was a famous Boise-area photographer who captured many iconic Boise images. His photojournalism career started in 1943%comma% and he took photographs up until his death in 2002 at the age of 81. His photos appeared in The Idaho Statesman. Leeburn has been labeled "the unofficial photographer-at-large%comma%" and "a Boise institution." His photographs show life in Boise in the 1940s from work to a variety of activities.

Title: Utah Statehood Constitutional Convention (1895) Records
Publisher: Published by Utah State Archives
Article Text:
%newline%On July 1894%comma% the U.S. Congress enacted a law to enable the territory of Utah to be admitted into the Union as a state. The act spelled out the calling of a convention composed of 107 delegates to meet beginning in March 1895 to draw up a state constitution. These records are the papers of that convention. They include a copy of the federal enabling act; roll call; transcripts%comma% published and unpublished%comma% of the proceedings; files of proposals%comma% petitions%comma% and other recommendations for inclusion in the state constitution; and a limited number of committee reports%comma% minutes and notes.

%newline%

Title: Dreaming the Skyline: Resort Architecture and the New Urban Space
Publisher: Published by University of Nevada%comma% Las Vegas%comma% University Libraries
Article Text:
%newline%From the El Rancho to CityCenter%comma% the Las Vegas Strip with its mega-resort hotel/casinos has developed a distinctive architectural style and type%comma% which has now been copied and exported to other gaming and resort cities throughout the world. Not only has this architecture transformed the physical environment of Las Vegas%comma% it has become a leitmotif for post-modern architecture. Aesthetically eclectic%comma% it has become a hallmark of the themed amusement park that characterizes the new urban entertainment and recreational space.

%newline%

Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Harold Mace was born and raised in Kanab%comma% UT. He was the only professional photographer in the greater Kanab area in the 1940s and 1950s. He was very civic-minded and recorded on film many of the events that happened in Kanab%comma% Kane County%comma% and the Fredonia%comma% Arizona area. He took the children's school pictures and his camera was at many school sports events. He photographed many weddings and family portraits. He also photographed documents for people to be preserved since copy machines were not available. Before he passed away%comma% he donated hundreds of photographs%comma% negatives and his early equipment to the Kanab Heritage Museum so that they could be preserved.
Article Text:
%newline%Harold loved gardening%comma% hunting%comma% fishing and camping with his family. He loved music and played several instruments%comma% including the harmonica and mandolin. He played with a small band for 20 years%comma% and played often at senior citizen homes in the Kanab and Hurricane%comma% Utah area. He passed away in 2008 but left a monumental legacy in photographs for others to enjoy today.

%newline%This collection is currently unavailable.

Title: Weber Academy Catalogue 1908-1918
Publisher: Published by Weber State University - Stewart Library
Article Text:
%newline%

This collection consists of the annual catalogs issued by Weber through six different name changes. The first catalog was issued in 1897 for the Weber Stake Academy when the academy was affiliated with the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. In 1908 the school became known as the Weber Academy%comma% and changing its name again to Weber Normal College in 1918. By 1922 the institution had changed its name to Weber College and in 1935; the church transferred the institution to the State of Utah. As the school continued to evolve%comma% it became known as Weber State College in 1963%comma% and finally in 1991 it gained university status and became known as Weber State University. The catalogs in this collection provide a rich history of the evolution of courses being taught throughout the progression of the institution.

%newline%

Note: 1869.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image) (Null image description)
Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%

In 1899%comma% Edward Curtis joined The Harriman Expedition to Alaska as the official photographer. On the expedition Curtis met George Bird Grinnell%comma% an expert on the Plains Indians. Grinnell shared Curtis's ideas concerning the conservation of American Indian traditions. Curtis accompanied Grinnell on a similar trip to Montana in 1900; this time to document the cultures of the Blackfoot%comma% Algonquin%comma% and Blood tribes. While viewing the Sun Dance of the Blackfoot Indians%comma% Grinnell told Curtis%comma% "Take a good look. We're not going to see this kind of thing much longer. It already belongs to the past." Curtis was so moved by his experiences with the American Indians of Alaska and Montana that he vowed to create a multi-volume encyclopedic reference on all of the American Indian Tribes which he would eventually title%comma% The North American Indian%comma% A Series of Volumes Picturing and Describing the Indians of the United States and Alaska.

%newline%

Curtis began his work with the Apache%comma% Jicarilla%comma% and Navajo tribes. The Navajo tribe he worked with was located in Canyon de Chelly in Arizona. Curtis wanted a more immersive experience than the typical tourist. So he hired an interpreter and a Navajo informant to communicate through and form relationships with the Navajo people. Instead of simply viewing the ceremonies%comma% Curtis now had insight into the meaning of each ceremony. For the second volume of the work%comma% Curtis documented the cultures of the Pima%comma% Papago%comma% Qahatika%comma% Mohave%comma% Yuma%comma% Maricopa%comma% Walapai%comma% Havasupai%comma% and Apache-Mohave or Yavapai tribes. Curtis returned to Arizona to work with the Hopi tribes of the Arizona for the twelfth volume.

%newline%

Altogether%comma% the twenty volumes produced by Edward Curtis represent a grand attempt to represent the various cultures of the American Indians. The twenty volume set%comma% with the twenty accompanying portfolios%comma% containing over 1%comma%500 photograph plates%comma% was not obtainable at an affordable price for most people. The volumes were sold mostly to institutions and private collectors.

%newline%

The description element of many of these objects comes directly from Curtis. The archaic spellings and awkward grammar are authentically Curtis's. In cases where Curtis did not supply captions to a plate%comma% corresponding sections of his writing from The North American Indian were used.

%newline%
Browse Link: %newline%Browse all records in

Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%

Building upon a partnership established in 2011%comma% the Arizona Capitol Museum and the Arizona Memory Project have partnered to create this exhibit to celebrate International Council of Museums' "International Museum Day." Images of the Arizona Capitol Museum is a virtual tour of the permanent exhibits at the Arizona Capitol Museum. IMD projects created by the Central Arizona Museum Association members are registered with the ICOM. For more information about IMD%comma% visit ICOM's Museum Day website.

%newline%

Welcome to a virtual tour of the Arizona Capitol Museum. Beginning at the main entrance of the Museum's historic Greek Revival exterior and continuing through each exhibit to the fourth floor where life-size figures from Arizona's past reside%comma% this virtual tour attempts to capture the basic elements of the Museum. Also included in this virtual tour are Arizona's Great Seal%comma% a 17-foot tall Greek goddess atop a copper dome%comma% and exhibits explaining Arizona's history%comma% water rights%comma% government structure and process%comma% and statehood. The Arizona Capitol Museum also has many traveling exhibits that are not included in this virtual tour. Visit the majestic Arizona Capitol Museum%comma% the building with the giant copper dome%comma% to really experience the history of Arizona.

%newline%

Title: Utah Governor Eli H. Murray (1880-1886) Thanksgiving Proclamation
Publisher: Published by Utah State Archives
Article Text:
%newline%

This printed proclamation was issued by Governor Eli H. Murray on November 18%comma% 1884 in response to custom and in obedience to the proclamation of the President of the United States setting aside Thursday November 27 as a day of public thanksgiving and prayer. The proclamations were apparently stamped with the state seal and distributed widely by Arthur L. Thomas%comma% Territorial Secretary. This example was transferred back to Utah from South Dakota.

Title: Utah Convention to Ratify the 21st Amendment (1933) Administrative Records
Publisher: Published by Utah State Archives
Article Text:
%newline%

The 72nd Congress of the United States proposed the 21st amendment to the U.S. Constitution%comma% repealing the 18th amendment and once again legalizing the manufacture and use of liquor. On October 10%comma% 1933%comma% Governor Henry H. Blood called for the election of delegates to a constitutional convention for the purpose of ratifying or rejecting the 21st amendment. The election was held on November 7%comma% and the elected delegates met December 5. The amendment became effective with the ratification of 36 states; Utah was the 36th state to ratify. These records document the activities of the convention.

%newline%

In 1930%comma% the first Southwest All-Indian Pow-Wow came to Flagstaff. This event%comma% centered around the Fourth of July%comma% featured rodeos%comma% parades%comma% authentic ceremonials%comma% and the sale of arts and crafts. It quickly became an occasion for celebration and attracted members of tribes from all over America. It was Flagstaff's primary festival for many years%comma% but the size of the crowds became unmanageable for Flagstaff residents. In 1980 Flagstaff decided to cancel the Pow-Wow permanently. This collection of historic powwow programs captures many of the images and stories behind this old tradition.

Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%

Prompted by her interest in Hopi arts and crafts%comma% Helga Teiwes%comma% photographer for the Arizona State Museum%comma% documented Hopi basket weavers over the course of three years in the early 1990's. Her efforts culminated into the book%comma% Hopi Basket Weaving%comma% Artistry in Natural Fibers. She captured the three styles of basketry woven at Hopi: the wicker basketry of Third Mesa%comma% the coiled basketry of Second Mesa and plaited basketry from all of the Mesas. In addition she documented the women who created these works of art and photographed the materials including siváapi (rabbitbrush)%comma% siwi (dune broom) suuvi (sumac) and mooho (yucca). Her photographs illustrate how the materials were gathered and prepared and show the weaving techniques used. This collection of photographs is a representative sample of Ms. Teiwes's work.

This collection includes postcards which represent Arizona subjects or were posted from Arizona post offices up until the year 1920. They are a visual demonstration of how Arizona has changed since the territorial period and many of the cards show towns%comma% buildings%comma% and ways of life which no longer exist. Messages on the reverse of these postcards comment on the experiences of inhabitants and visitors%comma% and as a whole%comma% this collection demonstrates how the postal service provided a vital means of communication for those wanting to stay in touch with people "back home."

Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%This collection traces the story of the University of Arizona Poetry Center from its modest beginnings in two Highland Avenue cottages to its permanent home in the award-winning Helen S. Schaefer Building. As the Poetry Center celebrated its 50th anniversary%comma% its current and former leaders looked back at the Center's history in a series of essays collected in The University of Arizona Poetry Center: Celebrating 50 Years. That volume is reproduced here%comma% together with photographs and reproductions of artifacts from the Poetry Center's institutional archives.

%newline%The Poetry Center was founded in 1960 by writer%comma% editor%comma% and philanthropist Ruth Stephan%comma% who envisioned a space where the public could "encounter poetry without intermediaries." Since that time%comma% the Poetry Center has expanded to become one of the premiere institutions of its kind in North America%comma% offering a world-class%comma% open-access special-collections poetry library and a wide variety of educational and outreach programming for writers%comma% readers%comma% and artists of all ages.

%newline%

Article Text:
%newline%Sun City%comma% AZ is the first active retirement community in the United States. As late as a month before Sun City's grand opening%comma% the development still did not have a name%comma% however that was by design. The Webb Construction Company%comma% to ramp up publicity%comma% had sponsored a nationwide contest to name the community. An ad was placed in the Saturday Evening Post%comma% awarding a new home to the winner. More than 100%comma%000 people came to see Sun City during its three-day weekend opening%comma% which began on January 1%comma% 1960. Del Webb%comma% the owner of Webb Construction Company was featured on the cover of the Time magazine on August 3%comma% 1962. A five page article on Del Webb%comma% his company and Sun City were in the magazine.  

%newline%
Arizona Memory Project

Most are primary documents that shed light on key historical happenings within the respective countries. Includes documents on Medieval and Renaissance Europe and on Europe as a supranational region. Offers access to documents on Andorra%comma% Iceland%comma% Denmark%comma% Finland%comma% France%comma% Germany%comma% and other countries. Links to a citation guide and to the Western European Specialist Section of the Association of College and Research Libraries (ACRL). Note: 1942.php has been marked for review (Null partner) (Null image description)
Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%

In April 1881%comma% the Helena City Council began meeting after the public approval of a charter incorporating the City of Helena. Minutes were created after each meeting and they detailed the actions of the mayor and aldermen in establishing the framework and continuance of their municipal government. The information typically captured in these minutes included the date%comma% time and location of the meeting%comma% the elected officials present%comma% members of the public who offered business for the council to consider%comma% and any action taken by the council. These minutes were handwritten in a bound volume. When a volume%comma% or minute book%comma% was filled%comma% a new one was started and this process continued. Handwritten minutes were kept in this fashion until October 1910%comma% when minutes were then typewritten. Each successive volume was continuously and carefully maintained in secure storage by the Helena City Clerk%comma% such that today a complete history of the activity of Helena's governing body exists. These bound volumes are carefully secured and maintained by the City Clerk and staff to the present day.

%newline%

%newline%

 

%newline%

Note: 1958.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%The Butte-Silver Bow Public Archives collections are comprehensive and interrelated and provide dynamic insights into the second Industrial revolution -the electrification of America-the history of copper mining and the rise of the Gibraltar of the labor movement in the American West. Butte%comma% Montana is home of the world's largest copper deposit%comma% once one of the most radically and ethnically diverse settlements of the West. The Butte-Silver Bow Public Archives actively collects manuscripts%comma% documents%comma% photographs%comma% and maps pertaining to Butte-Silver Bow. The Archives holds some 2%comma%000 collections in its state-of-the-art building. The records and manuscripts provide essential information on a number of subjects including the history of technology%comma% environmental history%comma% the history of women and minority groups and industrial and labor history.

%newline%

Note: 1959.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%Charles Hauswirth was born in Butte%comma% Montana in 1882 to Simon and Mary Hauswirth. In 1906 Hauswirth was a grocer at Forrest and Hauswirth Grocer%comma% and later he owned the Western Fuel Company. In 1932 Hauswirth started the "Eye Opener%comma%" a self-published newspaper%comma% which served as a venue for him to voice his thoughts on the economic troubles of the 1930s. After two unsuccessful campaigns for commissioner and sheriff%comma% he was nominated for mayor in 1935 as a Republican. He was the first mayor in Butte to serve more than two terms%comma% serving four terms. Hauswirth was a member of the Butte Exchange Club%comma% Butte Lodge No. 240%comma% BPOE%comma% and the Masonic Fraternity. Hauswirth died at his home on April 11%comma% 1941%comma% shortly after winning his fourth re-election.

%newline%
AMP Image Version: <amp-img src="../images/collection_images/collection1959.jpg" width="200" height="283" alt="Charles Hauswirth Portrait" layout = "responsive"></amp-img>

The landscape of Butte today is filled with historic buildings and headframes%comma% along with outdoor areas like the Highland Mountains and the nearby Boulder River. This collection contains books%comma% pamphlets%comma% scrapbooks%comma% articles%comma% and photographs exploring and showcasing the Butte area's rich history%comma% including privately held items contributed by community members.

%newline%The town of Big Timber was settled in south central Montana when the Northern Pacific Railroad arrived in 1882. By 1892%comma% Big Timber was one of the world's largest exporters of wool%comma% shipping out as much as 2 million pounds a year.The Big Timber Pioneer newspaper started in 1889 and is still in print today.This collection of newspapers begins with 1893 when Big Timber had a population of 500 and follows the community through its colorful history - including adventures with Native Americans%comma% the arrival of Chinese and Norwegian immigrants%comma% the big fire on Friday the 13th (March 1908)%comma% the decline of the wool industry%comma% the rise of cattle and cowboys%comma% and lots more.

%newline%The Prospector%comma% the student-produced Carroll College newspaper%comma% began publication in 1911. From its founding in 1909 until 1932 the College's name was Mount St. Charles College. Until 1922%comma% the Prospector consisted of articles on historical and contemporary topics%comma% poetry%comma% and a small amount of local news and reportage on College athletics. From September 1975 through April 1977 the newspaper changed its name to The Tumbleweed; it continued as The Prospector in September 1977. The newspaper is not published during the summer and has been issued irregularly%comma% with anywhere from two to twelve issues within the academic year.

Note: 1979.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%During World War II%comma% Fort Missoula in Missoula%comma% Montana%comma% was turned over to the Department of Justice%comma% Immigration and Naturalization Service for use as an Alien Detention Center (ADC) to hold foreign nationals and resident aliens. This collection includes correspondence%comma% telegrams%comma% memoranda and maps documenting the creation of the Fort Missoula Detention Camp between 1941 and 1942. The majority of the records originate from Willard F. Kelly%comma% Chief Supervisor of Border Patrol%comma% Immigration and Naturalization Service. Details are provided about the construction of new facilities; the renovation of existing facilities; the securing of supplies including vaccinations%comma% clothing and food; and other logistics such as sanitation and entertainment. Some documents include personal information about the detainees including name%comma% rank%comma% age%comma% hometown%comma% and marital status. Some of the documents also relate to provisioning Fort Lincoln just south of Bismarck%comma% North Dakota. Between 1941 and 1944%comma% the ADC held 1%comma%200 non-military Italian men%comma% 1%comma%000 Japanese resident aliens%comma% 23 German resident aliens%comma% and 123 Japanese Latin and South Americans. The 1%comma%200 Italian men were merchant seamen%comma% World's Fair employees and the crew of an Italian luxury liner seized in the Panama Canal. Many of the Italians%comma% who referred to the Fort as "Bella Vista%comma%" spent the war as paid laborers replacing American men working in forestry%comma% farms%comma% the sugar beet industry and constructing Highway 12. Following the bombing of Pearl Harbor on December 7%comma% 1941%comma% the FBI arrested more than a 1%comma%000 of the most prominent Japanese leaders on the west coast as potential security risks. Ultimately%comma% over 1%comma%000 Japanese men -- all resident aliens barred by law from American citizenship -- were held at Fort Missoula for loyalty hearings. None was ever charged with any act of disloyalty but all were held at Fort Missoula or other camps for the duration of the war. A handful of German resident aliens were held for short periods at Fort Missoula%comma% although most were held at Fort Lincoln in Bismarck%comma% North Dakota. The 123 men of Japanese ancestry from Latin and South America%comma% mostly Peru%comma% were a very small part of several thousand held primarily at the Santa Fe camp or at Crystal City%comma% Texas. The documents in this collection were scanned from notebooks maintained by the Historical Museum at Fort Missoula. These notebooks contain only photocopies. Documents which include medical or case file information about detainees have not been made available. There are indications that the original documents were held at one time in the record vault of the Missoula County Records office. Official records of internment camps%comma% including those of Fort Missoula%comma% are held by the National Archives and Records Administration in RG 85.

%newline%
AMP Image Version: <amp-img src="../images/collection_images/collection1979.jpg" width="273" height="350" alt="Correspondence to District Director" layout = "responsive"></amp-img>
Browse Link: %newline%Browse all records in

Note: 1980.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%The Boone and Crockett Club was the United States' first hunting and big game conservation organization. It was founded by Theodore Roosevelt in 1887 and continues to this day. Its mission is "to promote the conservation and management of wildlife%comma% especially big game and its habitat%comma% to preserve and encourage hunting%comma% and to maintain the highest ethical standards of fair chase and sportsmanship in North America."

%newline%Among its many activities%comma% the Club advocated for passage of conservation laws and policies such as the Alaska Game Law%comma% the establishment of Glacier and Mt. McKinley (now Denali) National Parks%comma% a bill to enlarge Yellowstone National Park%comma% and many forest reserve and game refuge bills. The Club was able to lend effective support to conservation efforts due to its notable members%comma% including Aldo Leopold%comma% Gifford Pinchot%comma% Theodore Roosevelt%comma% George Bird Grinnell%comma% Charles Sheldon%comma% John F. Lacey%comma% Stephen Mather%comma% Jay N. "Ding" Darling%comma% and many other prominent conservationists.

%newline%

Note: 1982.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%Evelyn J. Cameron was a pioneer photographer and rancher in eastern Montana. Originally from England%comma% she moved to Montana with her husband Ewen in 1893. Evelyn kept extensive diaries from 1893 until her death in 1928. The diaries (35 in total) presented here chronicle her daily life including books she read%comma% chores%comma% lists of letters written and received%comma% local and national events%comma% photographs taken%comma% social activities%comma% verbatim copies of special letters%comma% and weather. The diaries also include innumerable tidbits of information that reveal the fabric of her life and by extension that of many women in eastern Montana at the time. For instance%comma% her diaries include the number of eggs gathered and chickens killed per month; notes on the amount of butter she churned; methods of skinning a coyote and breaking a horse; accounts of money made from her photos and garden produce; lists of supplies; and Evelyn's favorite poems and quotes. In order to make ends meet%comma% Evelyn also became an accomplished photographer%comma% working for hire for local families wanting to record special events. Her images capture the surprising ethnic and cultural diversity that marked life in the Terry%comma% Montana area in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The diaries record when and where she took images%comma% for whom%comma% why and on what occasions%comma% and what her thoughts were at the time. Taken together the images and diaries provide wonderful insights into the life of early eastern Montana ranch families.

%newline%
AMP Image Version: <amp-img src="../images/collection_images/collection1982.jpg" width="383" height="234" alt="1896 Diary of Evelyn Cameron" layout = "responsive"></amp-img>
Browse Link: %newline%Browse all records in

Article Text:
%newline%These locally produced books of 100-1000 pages contain the rich%comma% detailed stories of small Montana communities from the homestead era and beyond. Fully searchable by keyword%comma% the books include family histories%comma% photographs%comma% maps%comma% diary excerpts%comma% letters%comma% and first-hand recollections of significant events. This growing collection currently covers 29 of Montana's 56 counties.

Article Text:
%newline%Rosetta Kamlowsky was one of the first female broadcasters in Montana. She hosted the Scooter radio show on KBLL Radio beginning in 1968. This is a collection of those interviews dating from the 1960s to the 1980s.

Note: 1995.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%Thomas Brown Brook (1890-1966) was the son of a Nevada City gold miner who came to Montana in 1863. His father%comma% John Brook%comma% established a ranch on the Beaverhead River eight miles south of Twin Bridges%comma% Montana in 1870%comma% and Thomas grew up on the ranch and attended local schools. He graduated from Gallatin County High School in Bozeman and in 1913 earned a degree in Civil Engineering from Montana State College. After working on a ranch and serving in France during World War I%comma% Brook returned to Twin Bridges%comma% where he worked as an electrician. As a hobby%comma% Brook began taking photographs of various locations in and around Twin Bridges. Eventually%comma% he engaged in copying historical photographs brought to him by various individuals. Before his death in 1966%comma% Brook had compiled a substantial collection of both original and copied photographs. The Thomas Brook Photograph Collection consists of nature landscapes and town views of southwest Montana%comma% particularly in the Twin Bridges area of Madison and Beaverhead Counties. Subjects include natural history%comma% ranch and farming operations%comma% bridges and bridge construction%comma% mining and timber outfits%comma% schools and school groups%comma% and early settlers of the Twin Bridges area.

%newline%
AMP Image Version: <amp-img src="../images/collection_images/collection1995.jpg" width="240" height="159" alt="First Train in Twin Bridges" layout = "responsive"></amp-img>
Browse Link: %newline%Browse all records in

Note: 1996.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%August "Gus" Ludwig Hormay (1907-1999) developed the rest-rotation grazing management system of the Western United States rangelands and spent more than seventy years working in natural resource conservation. In 1931%comma% after he completed his academic studies at the University of California%comma% Berkeley%comma% Hormay started working for the United States Department of Agriculture Forest Service. For the next thirty-six years%comma% Hormay worked out of the Pacific Southwest Forest and Range Experiment Station in Berkeley%comma% California and developed the theory of rest-rotation. In 1966%comma% Hormay transferred to the Bureau of Land Management and spearheaded the education of government officials%comma% land stewards%comma% and livestock holders in rest-rotation grazing techniques. The Hormay Collection of his personal and professional papers includes daily activities during 1930-1999; numerous publications; research files on Modoc National Forest%comma% Lassen National Forest%comma% and Plumas National Forest; experimental forests and ranges of Blacks Mountain Experimental Forest%comma% Burgess Spring Experimental Range%comma% and Harvey Valley Grazing Allotment; grazing allotments and rangelands throughout the intermountain and Trans-Mississippi West 1965-1977; and Hormay's experiments with reproduction and germination of bitterbrush (Purshia tridentata) 1942-1979.

%newline%
AMP Image Version: <amp-img src="../images/collection_images/collection1996.jpg" width="308" height="400" alt="Montana Governors records 1889-1962" layout = "responsive"></amp-img>
Browse Link: %newline%Browse all records in

Note: 1997.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%James Willard Schultz (1859-1947) lived in and wrote about the northwestern portion of Montana which now includes the Blackfeet Reservation and Glacier National Park. In 1877%comma% at the age of 18%comma% he traveled from his birthplace in Boonville%comma% New York to Fort Benton%comma% Montana Territory. He became interested in American Indians%comma% and lived for many years with the Blackfeet Indians as an accepted member of their nation. Drawing upon his experiences on the western frontier%comma% he wrote books and articles to make a living as an author. The Schultz Collection includes photographs of Blackfeet%comma% Blood%comma% Kutenai%comma% Shoshoni and Arapaho Native Americans%comma% Glacier and Waterton Lakes National Parks%comma% and historic views of Montana%comma% Wyoming%comma% and Arizona.

%newline%

Note: 2000.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%Early day Polson%comma% Montana%comma% located on the beautiful shores of Flathead Lake%comma% boasted two weekly newspapers%comma% The Flathead Courier and The Lake Shore Sentinel. Their small-town stories and articles%comma% pictures%comma% and ads for long-ago products and businesses give a clear glimpse into Polson/Lake County life during the early years of the twentieth century. Both newspapers show the vibrant history of this prospering Montana location. In 1911%comma% The Lake Shore Sentinel consolidated with The Flathead Courier. World news continued to mingle with local editorial comments%comma% homestead news%comma% school happenings%comma% births and deaths%comma% and farm and ranch news%comma% along with details like stage coach and ferry schedules.

%newline%

Note: 2013.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%Arizona Highways magazine was born in the early 1920s. As automobiles emerged as the preferred mode of transportation in the U.S.%comma% a handful of states throughout the country developed magazines to entice motorists to travel newly developed roads. Sponsored by the states' departments of transportation%comma% these magazines provide a unique resource for examining how the automobile changed the history of travel and helped to shape identities of place in America. Of these magazines%comma% none date as far back or have featured the iconic photography that has made Arizona Highways a national treasure.

%newline%

Title: Weber Additional Literary Publications 1931-1980
Publisher: Published by Weber State University - Stewart Library
Article Text:
%newline% Spanning from 1931 to 1980%comma% Weber State had many different literary publications.Some periodicals had a longer run than others%comma% but all provide an interesting feel for the social life of their time and a glimpse into Weber's past. The publications included are The Acorn Crumb from 1931 – 34; Scribulus ran from 1935 – 66 and doubled as a yearbook for several years; Transit from 1942 – 43; The Selector in 1948; The New Touch in 1948; Probe from 1968 – 72; Kaleidoscope in 1968; and The Aardvark Review from 1978 – 80. These publications include writings%comma% photographs and history submitted by students%comma% faculty and alumni.

Title: Jack London Collection
Publisher: Published by Utah State University - Merrill-Cazier Library
Article Text:
%newline%This selective small digital collection highlights his will%comma% letters%comma% and book inscriptions that offer insights into his complex relationships with the important women in his life: first wife Bessie%comma% second wife Charmian%comma% daughters Joan and Bess%comma% mother Flora%comma% "mammy" Jennie%comma% and friend/collaborator Anna Strunsky. Other items in the digital collection include photographs and book covers. For more details about London's life as well as a full inventory of USU's larger print collection of Jack and Charmian London materials%comma% please visit this link.

Title: Alfred G. Erickson Photograph Collection
Publisher: Published by Utah State University - Merrill-Cazier Library
Article Text:
%newline%Cache Valley native Alfred Gordon Erickson attended Utah State Agricultural College in the second half of the 1940s following his service in the Army Air Force during World War II. The 255 black and white photographs in this digital collection were taken by Erickson between 1940 and 1950 while he was with the Army in California and a college student at USAC in Logan%comma% Utah. Of particular interest are several views of Jack London's ranch%comma% visited by Erickson while he was based in California.

%newline%
