Title: Utah Legislature. House of Representatives Working Bills%comma% 1896-1989
Publisher: Published by Utah State Archives
Article Text:
%newline%This series documents the legislative process in the House of Representatives. The series contains the working copies of House bills%comma% claims (through 1915)%comma% petitions (until 1921)%comma% memorials%comma% reports (1897 only) and resolutions. The working copy includes the bill as introduced and any amendments made to it. The final official version of the bill is not part of this series unless it was vetoed by the Governor%comma% returned to the Legislature while still in session%comma% and the Legislature failed to override the veto.

%newline%

Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library

Article Text:
%newline%Danvers is a small agricultural community settled largely by Bohemian Catholics and located on the Milwaukee Road. St. Wenceslaus Church%comma% a symbol of the Bohemian religious and cultural heritage%comma% was built in 1916. Much of the town's social gatherings revolved around the church and the hall located across the road.

Note: 2067.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%James T. Annin%comma% eldest son of Senator Joseph (J. B.) and Janet (Haldine) Annin%comma% was born in Livingston%comma% MT%comma% and moved with his family to Columbus in 1892. After graduating with the first senior class of Columbus in 1906%comma% he then graduated from Montana State College (Bozeman) and became the publisher for the Columbus News until 1932. He went on to become a rancher%comma% forester%comma% and state representative%comma% as well as secretary and finance officer of the state Republican party. In 1960 he began the collection and copying of photographs of Stillwater families%comma% which%comma% along with text%comma% became the three-part county history mentioned in the cross-reference above. Originally intended as something less comprehensive than the ultimate end product%comma% the photograph collection grew to over 2%comma%300 8 x 10 inch prints before the history was published in 1964. Many of the photographs are composites of several smaller snapshots; some were not included in They Gazed upon the Beartooths; others were included without explanation as to their subjects' significance in the settling of Stillwater County.

Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%Eureka%comma% Montana didn't always have a newspaper. For many years the Lincoln County High School student newspapers served as the community paper with their biweekly publication during the school year. The Evergreen and Ksanka carried stories%comma% articles and ads for the community in addition to school news. The paper had student editorials on local happenings%comma% and farm%comma% ranch and logging reports along with Libby Dam preconstruction articles. Some local births and deaths were news items%comma% along with club meeting%comma% accidents%comma% weddings%comma% and hunting successes. These newspapers were vital to the Tobacco Valley of Northwest Montana and today much of the history of the region is preserved through the papers.

%newline%

Article Text:
%newline%The photos of Armstead%comma% Montana depict a town that disappeared beneath Happy Hawkins lake behind the Clark Canyon Dam in the early 1960's. It was important because it was the site of Camp Fortunate where the Lewis and Clark Expedition met the Shoshone Indians and Sacajawea recognized her brother. Both the Union Pacific Train that ran from Salt Lake City to Butte and the Gilmore and Pittsburg Railroad had depots there. The collection was housed in the archives of the Beaverhead County Museum where the originals continue to be held.

Note: 2074.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%This digital collection consists of speeches by%comma% statements of%comma% and interviews with Mike Mansfield drawn from the extensive Mike Mansfield Papers held at The University of Montana's Mansfield Library. Mike Mansfield was elected to the U.S. House of Representatives in 1942 and served five terms as representative of Montana's 1st District. He was elected to the U.S. Senate in 1952 and reelected in 1958%comma% 1964 and 1970. He became Assistant Majority Leader (Majority Whip) of the Senate in January 1957%comma% and served in that capacity until 1961%comma% when he was elected Majority Leader of the Senate. He held that position until he retired from the Senate in 1977 - longer than any other Majority Leader in the history of the U.S. Senate.

%newline%

Title: Monumental Highway Collection
Publisher: Published by Utah State University - Merrill-Cazier Library
Article Text:
%newline%Monument Valley%comma% with skyward reaching red rock monuments%comma% has long been symbolic of the rugged deserts of the American West. However%comma% before Western films%comma% television shows%comma% and commercials established its fame%comma% Monument Valley was virtually inaccessible for locals and tourists. Even after the invention of the automobile%comma% the absence of an effective road system in the harsh terrain did little to heighten its accessibility. Dolph Andrus%comma% of Bluff%comma% Utah%comma% set out to change that and was convinced that he could open Monument Valley to automobile tourism.

%newline%In the Spring of 1917%comma% Andrus left Bluff%comma% Utah with William H. Hopkins%comma% a dentist and enthusiastic photographer%comma% to complete an automobile journey through Monument Valley%comma% on to Kayenta%comma% Tuba City%comma% and Lee’s Ferry%comma% Arizona. Later that summer%comma% Andrus set off again with photographer%comma% L. W. Clement with the intent to photograph the natural bridges and monuments of the valley. Andrus’s wife%comma% Irene%comma% and daughter%comma% Torma%comma% accompanied them on this trip in which burros were used for transportation.

%newline%The bulk of this collection consists of the photographs taken during these tours of Monument Valley%comma% Natural Bridges National Monuments%comma% Zion National Park%comma% the Colorado River%comma% and the San Juan River. Andrus's Maxwell automobile is featured in many of the images. Also in the collection is the personal history of Dolph and Irene Andrus and log of these trips. The Monumental Highway Digital Collection is comprised of the Dolph Andrus Monumental Highway Photograph Collection (P0360) and the Dr. William H. Hopkins Addendum Collection (P0542).

%newline%Please visit the Dolph Andrus's Monumental Highway Expeditions Digital Exhibit for more information.

%newline%Torma at the wheel of her first car

Title: Utah Humanities Research Foundation
Publisher: Published by University of Utah - J. Willard Marriott Library
Article Text:
%newline%This collection consists of historical materials collected by the Foundation. Included are letters%comma% articles%comma% family histories%comma% town and county histories%comma% biographies%comma% and miscellaneous materials on Utah cultural history. Business correspondence relates to the publication of the Utah (later Western) Humanities Review%comma% including Dale Morgan's bibliographies of the lesser Mormon churches. Correspondents also include Bernard De Voto and Wallace Stegner. Also included are a small quantity of business records of the Foundation%comma% a manuscript and galley proofs of the first issue of the Utah Humanities Review%comma% and records of the Warshaw Essay Contest.

Title: Utah Pioneer Costume Research Project
Publisher: Published by University of Utah - J. Willard Marriott Library
Article Text:
%newline%The purpose of the Utah Pioneer Costume Research Project was to photograph%comma% record and annotate historic dress and define the relation of Utah pioneer dress to the general development of costume in the United States. It attempts to find similarities between Utah pioneer dress and the characteristics of the fashion of 1977%comma% to find in what ways Utah pioneer dress differed from these%comma% and to find what additions were made to the fashion of 1977 by Utah pioneer dress. The conclusions reached were that Utah pioneer dress%comma% from 1847-1875%comma% followed the general characteristics of 1977 fashion because the women had an interest in dress. But pioneer dress differed in certain details from 1977 fashion too.

%newline%

Historic native cultures are well represented%comma% with black-and-white as well as color drawings of Maricopa%comma% Pima%comma% Mohave%comma% and Yuman objects; especially numerous are examples of Pima baskets. There are detailed architectural drawings%comma% floor plans%comma% and color renditions of native houses. There are also examples of the use of the "swastika" motif in art%comma% throughout time and around the world.

Note: 2085.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%This collection documents the restoration of Phoenix's Block 14. Located at the heart of downtown Phoenix%comma% Block 14 is the only remaining residential block from the original Phoenix townsite. As the city grew over time%comma% Block 14 and other residential areas were encompassed by commercial development. Over the years%comma% many homes fell into disrepair and were demolished.

In the early 1970s%comma% Phoenix's urban renewal campaigns targeted Block 14 for razing. A community effort spearheaded by former Phoenix Mayor%comma% John Driggs%comma% resulted in the City of Phoenix purchasing the Rosson House and the remainder of the homes in Block 14. This highly successful community and governmental partnership led to the creation of a park which was named Heritage Square.

At the center of the project was the restoration of the Rosson House. A group of dedicated volunteers meticulously restored this Phoenix landmark to its 1895 condition. Originally intended to be a meeting house%comma% the Rosson House soon morphed into a museum. During the restoration of Heritage Square%comma% other buildings were also restored and infrastructure was added to the park.

Our physical collection consists of 4 linear feet of documents and approximately 2%comma%000 photographs. In 2011%comma% this collection received a grant from the Historical Records Advisory Board to aid with its preservation.

%newline%

Title: Chicano Scholarship Archive
Publisher: Published by University of Utah - J. Willard Marriott Library
Article Text:
%newline%Prior to 1970%comma% few Utah Chicanos had attended the University of Utah and even fewer had graduated. Low educational attainment and financial hardship were some of the factors which prevented Utah's Chicano population from pursuing higher education. As a result%comma% a group of University Chicano faculty%comma% community representatives and students felt a need to recognize and encourage those outstanding Chicano students who were willing to provide quality service to the community while maintaining academic excellence. This collection contains videos and images of Chicano scholars at the University of Utah.

Note: 2092.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%The Merci Train Collection contains a sampling of items from the 1949 Merci (Gratitude) Train. "Merci" means thank you in French. Each boxcar was filled with gifts from the people of France showing their gratitude to the American people for sending food and other supplies on the Friendship Train and for liberating France from the invading German army during World War II. The Merci Train Collection contains various objects%comma% such as paper stars%comma% photographs%comma% clothing%comma% tablecloths%comma% pillows%comma% toys%comma% paintings%comma% books%comma% trench art%comma% glassware%comma% and lovely dolls showing the traditional dress of several French provinces. A Peugeot bicycle and a wedding dress grace the Merci Train Exhibit in the Arizona Capitol Museum. The following items also can be seen in the exhibit: a crystal ashtray%comma% paintings%comma% a commemorative medal%comma% a glass hand mirror%comma% handmade stars%comma% tourist publications%comma% books%comma% souvenir postcards%comma% hand-painted postcards%comma% a religious medal%comma% a Napoleon Medal%comma% and children's clothing and toys.

%newline%

Note: 2093.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%The Area that is now Petrified Forest National Park has been attracting people to its unique resources for at least 13%comma%000 years. Because of the many fossils of Triassic animals and plants which include everything from the bones of early dinosaurs and crocodile like animals%comma% to fossil leaves%comma% pollen%comma% and large deposits of petrified trees that all lived between 225 and 208 million years ago%comma% this place could be called Petrified Ecosystem National Park. In addition to tourists the park currently attracts geologists%comma% paleontologists%comma% historians%comma% and also artists who come to capture the beautiful and scenic landscape.

%newline%Hundreds of archaeological sites have been discovered in this area. These include everything from some of the earliest North American spear points to Pueblo IV age habitations which date to about the time of European settlement. This incredible diversity of natural and cultural resources makes the park a research hotbed with dozens of academic partners and a strong record of publications. As an example%comma% in early 2014 a geologic core (a thin tube of rock) taller than the Empire State Building was extracted from the park by an international team of geologists seeking to learn about climate change and extinctions during the Triassic time period.

%newline%Many years of southwestern history and culture are represented within Petrified Forest National Park and some have been captured in this collection of photographs. From prehistoric peoples to early explorers%comma% from the Civilian Conservation Corps to Historic Route 66%comma% the park has many stories to tell.

%newline%

%newline%A digital collection comprised of historical photographs of Moscow%comma% Idaho and the surrounding Latah County. The photos were collected by Clifford M. Ott and donated to the University of Idaho Library in 1992. Mr. Ott was an avid amateur photographer who amassed over 10%comma%000 slides%comma% prints%comma% and negatives spanning the years from 1883 to 1990. Ott compiled a selection from his collection into eleven albums containing a total of over 1%comma%800 images of Moscow%comma% Idaho and surrounding Latah County. These scrap books contain photos as well as newspaper clippings%comma% and historic footnotes. Clifford Ott used these scrapbooks%comma% and other slides and negatives%comma% to give talks to senior groups about Latah County history.

Title: Leonard Feather Jazz Collection
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%Jazz journalist Leonard Geoffrey Feather was born in Hampstead%comma% England on September 13%comma% 1914. In the 1930s%comma% he arranged%comma% composed%comma% and produced jazz sessions%comma% and began to write about jazz for print media.  After moving to New York he worked with such greats as Louis Armstrong%comma% Dizzy Gillespie%comma% and Duke Ellington%comma% establishing his reputation in various fields of jazz.  Writing for famous jazz journals and authoring several books%comma% he was particularly influential in promoting Bebop.  Moving to Los Angeles in 1960%comma% he became the chief jazz critic for the Los Angeles Times. Leonard Feather died on September 22%comma% 1994.

%newline%The Leonard Feather Papers span the years 1900–1999%comma% with the bulk of the materials dating 1935–1990%comma% approximately. Included among the papers are photographs%comma% negatives%comma% scrapbooks and photo albums%comma% pamphlets%comma% notebooks%comma% sketches%comma% scores%comma% soundsheets%comma% correspondence%comma% clippings%comma% manuscripts (including those for books%comma% articles%comma% liner notes%comma% and radio and television productions)%comma% promotional materials%comma% research materials%comma% travel and teaching notes%comma% royalty statements and other financial papers%comma% lists of Mr. Feather's personal collections (audio cassettes%comma% records%comma% and video tapes)%comma% ephemera%comma% and papers related to Mr. Feather's last illness and documents gathered after his death.

%newline%

Title: Stacks: Idaho's Digital Repository - Additional State Agencies

Article Text:
%newline%[Stacks]%comma% the Idaho Digital Repository%comma% is a cooperative project of the Idaho Commission for Libraries and all state agencies. It is a searchable centralized collection of digital publications that are created by state agencies for the purpose of public information.

%newline% It was created by state statute 33-2505 which reads in part%comma% "Recognizing that an informed citizenry is a cornerstone of effective democracy%comma% and in order to provide free and continuous access to state publications%comma% it shall be the duty of the state librarian to establish and maintain a publicly accessible repository of publications prepared by state agencies. The digital repository is intended to collect state publications and make them readily available to all Idaho citizens."

Note: 2109.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%The site of Thunderbird School of Global Management has its origins as a primary flight training school during World War II. In the late 1930's%comma% with war looming on the horizon%comma% General "Hap" Arnold%comma% who authorized civilian training bases for World War II%comma% recognized a need to train more pilots for combat. However%comma% Congress disagreed%comma% and only allowed the expansion of one training base%comma% Randolph Field. Arnold circumvented Congress and sent out a call for civilian flight operators to gamble their dollars building training fields to teach Air Corps cadets how to fly. Out of this need%comma% Thunderbird Field was established.

%newline%Featured in the online collection are photographs of all of the Thunderbird Fields%comma% letters from cadets to their former instructors%comma% yearbooks%comma% company handbooks and other publications. Materials will be added to the online collection regularly.

%newline%

Browse Link: %newline%Browse all records in

Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%Marshall Trimble is considered the "Dean of Arizona Historians" and has taught Arizona history at Scottsdale Community College for 40 years. His first book was published in 1977 by Doubleday & Company%comma% New York. Since then he's written more than twenty books on Arizona and the West. Trimble is one of the state's most popular speakers and performers. He's also an educator%comma% lecturer%comma% folk singer and stage performer.

%newline%He was inducted into the Arizona Music and Entertainment Hall of Fame in February 2011. In March%comma% Marshall was the Grand Marshal in the Phoenix St. Patrick's Day Parade. That same year the Arizona Historical Society presented him their distinguished Al Merito Award in recognition of his lifetime service in promoting Arizona history. The Arizona Centennial Commission honored him in December 2011 as "One of Arizona's Most Inspiring Leaders."

Title: Stonebraker Photograph Collection
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%This collection consists of 540 photographs from the William Allen Stonebraker Collection%comma% which was donated to the University of Idaho Library in 2003. Stonebraker took photographs in Central Idaho's remote Salmon River and Frank Church-River of No Return wilderness at the turn of the twentieth century between 1900 and 1931. The collection contains images of the Stonebraker Ranch and homestead in the Chamberlain Basin%comma% his businesses (dude ranch%comma% pack train and dogsled operations%comma% mining%comma% big game hunting) as well as wildlife%comma% scenic views%comma% and early aircraft operation.

Title: Barre Toelken Fieldwork Image Collection
Publisher: Published by Utah State University - Merrill-Cazier Library
Article Text:
%newline%Featuring half a century (1954-2002) of folklore fieldwork%comma% the images in this digital collection were created by noted folklorist Barre Toelken and cover a range of folklore topics such as cemeteries%comma% Native Americans (mostly Navajo)%comma% folk art%comma% vernacular architecture%comma% and customs of Austria%comma% Germany%comma% Japan%comma% and the United States. The Barre Toelken Fieldwork Image Collection (Folk Coll 35a) is a donation from Barre Toelken%comma% emeritus Utah State University English (folklore) professor; originals are housed in the Fife Folklore Archives in Utah State University’s Merrill-Cazier Library%comma% Special Collections and Archives

Title: Central Utah Project: Capturing Utah's Share of the Colorado River
Publisher: Published by Utah State University - Merrill-Cazier Library
Article Text:
%newline%In this digital collection of 71 oral histories%comma% stakeholders from the Central Utah Water Conservancy District (CUWCD)%comma% Central Utah Project Completion Act (CUPCA)%comma% the Bureau of Reclamation (BOR) and the Ute Nation%comma% join with Utah water users%comma% members of the environmental community and Utah’s political establishment to tell the complex and oftentimes controversial story of the Central Utah Project (CUP). The CUP captures the excess flow of the Duchesne River and its tributaries in the Colorado River Basin of eastern Utah and transfers it to the Wasatch Front through a trans-mountain diversion consisting of pipelines%comma% tunnels and reservoirs. Originally under the purview of the BOR%comma% Congress transferred authority to complete the project to the CUWCD when it passed the unprecedented Central Utah Project Completion Act (P.L. 102-575) on 30 October 1992%comma% which created the Utah Reclamation Mitigation & Conservation Commission to assure environmental compliance. As a result of this legislation the Interior Department created the CUPCA office for oversight.

%newline%Commissioned by the CUWCD and CUPCA%comma% the oral history project is an effort by Utah State University Library’s Special Collections & Archives to preserve and present this fascinating story and to augment research for the forthcoming book on the CUP by Utah historians Craig Fuller%comma% Robert Parson and Ross Peterson. Randy Williams%comma% USU Fife Folklore Archives Curator and oral history specialist%comma% conducted the interviews (June 2012 - September 2013).

%newline%
AMP Image Version: <amp-img src="../images/collection_images/collection2117.jpg" alt="Frances Poowegup and Phillip Chimburas interview%comma% September 12%comma% 2012" height ="250" width="250" layout = "responsive"></amp-img>
Image Description: Frances Poowegup and Phillip Chimburas interview%comma% September 12%comma% 2012
Browse Link: %newline%Browse all records in Central Utah Project: Capturing Utah's Share of the Colorado River

Note: 2124.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%James Brownlee Rankin--a New York and San Bernadino%comma% California%comma% teacher and historian--collected information concerning Montana artist Charles M. Russell in preparation for a Russell biography and an illustrated catalog of his work. The collection consists primarily of correspondence concerning Russell's life and work as remembered by his friends%comma% acquaintances%comma% and art owners. This series%comma% constituting eighty percent of the collection%comma% is the most valuable for research on Russell and on ranching and cowboy life in the open range era. Many friends and acquaintances of Russell corresponded extensively with Rankin%comma% and their reminiscences would have been the basis of his book. Other correspondents discussed the Russell paintings and sculpture in their collections. The letters also reflect the provenance of much of the artist's work%comma% kinds of shows that it appeared in%comma% and methods by which it was acquired. The collection also contains photographs%comma% clippings%comma% and research notes. The Research Notes series of the collection contains listings of paintings%comma% notes on interviews%comma% and transcriptions of letters of Russell and others. Also%comma% there are several photographs of pieces of Russell's work owned by various institutions and individuals at that time. The collection is completed by a series of Clippings gathered by Rankin which generally concern Russell's life.

%newline%

Image Description: James Brownlee Rankin Box 1: Correspondence A-E

%newline%The State Law Library of Montana’s Justice Under the Big Sky collection pulls together a number of facets of the Montana legal system in a never-seen-before photo ensemble. Included in the collection are group photos of the Montana Supreme Court%comma% individual portraits of Montana Supreme Court Justices and Montana district court judges%comma% as well as Montana Judges Association group photos and historic photos of the State Law Library. Of particular interest in the collection are photos memorializing the groundbreaking of the current Montana Justice Building. The State Law Library strives to provide access to legal information for Montana's judges and court personnel%comma% members of the State Bar of Montana%comma% state officers and employees%comma% and members of the general public.

Note: 2126.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%The World Museum of Mining currently houses over 200 of John J. Powers’ screen prints. These screen prints were developed as safety posters for the Anaconda Copper Mining Company (ACM) in Butte%comma% Montana throughout the 1960s and 1970s. John Powers was a well-known cartoonist for the company’s safety department and also worked as a miner. This collection of prints is a stunning representation of safety procedures and examples%comma% both of men’s actions mining underground and taking part in everyday life above. The safety posters were designed and printed specifically for the safety department of the ACM. Unique by creator and location%comma% the posters are a treasure to the city of Butte and the state of Montana.

%newline%

Article Text:
%newline%The Bozeman and Gallatin Valley History Collection is largely made up of three collections that provide a glimpse of the area and its inhabitants during the early part of the twentieth century. The life of a cowboy on the famous Flying D Ranch is conveyed by photographs taken during the 1930-1940s by Jim Pratt and Bill Shunk. Early colorized photos of the Bozeman Pass and Gallatin Canyon are the work of Wyoming photographer Jessamine Spear Johnson during a visit in 1927. The excitement of Bozeman’s own first wildwest show and rodeo%comma% the 1920 Bozeman Roundup%comma% appears in images captured by an unknown photographer.

Title: San Francisco (CA) Earthquake Snapshots
Publisher: Published by Utah State University - Merrill-Cazier Library
Article Text:
%newline%A few minutes after five o’clock in the morning on April 18%comma% 1906%comma% huge shockwaves began wreaking havoc on the city of San Francisco%comma% California%comma% and in the immediate aftermath%comma% fires spread across the area. The combination of the earthquake and the fires destroyed over 80 percent of the city.

%newline% At the time of the earthquake%comma% John Lorin Taylor%comma% a native of Ogden%comma% Utah%comma% was traveling in San Francisco (possibly as a missionary for the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints) and witnessed the incident.This digital collection contains the 25 photographs that Taylor took on the day of the earthquake and the two days following. The images portray the devastating toll that the earthquake and subsequent fires took on the city and its inhabitants%comma% over 3%comma%000 of whom were killed%comma% and more than 225%comma%000 left homeless. The photographs include images of refugees as well as several notable buildings such as the Emporium%comma% James Flood%comma% the Examiner%comma% the Call%comma% Merchant’s Exchange building%comma% Hibernia Bank%comma% City Hall%comma%and the Central Bank – all of which were destroyed during the disaster.

%newline%
AMP Image Version: <amp-img src="../images/collection_images/collection2136.jpg" alt="%return%%newline%View of ruins from OFarrell and Larkin Streets after the San Francisco Fire and Earthquake%comma% San Francisco%comma% California%comma% April 20%comma% 1906%return%%newline%" width="300" height ="250" layout = "responsive"></amp-img>
Image Description: View of ruins from O'Farrell and Larkin Streets after the San Francisco Fire and Earthquake%comma% San Francisco%comma% California%comma% April 20%comma% 1906
Browse Link: %newline%Browse all records in San Francisco (CA) Earthquake Snapshots

Title: Bear Lake Monster
Publisher: Published by Utah State University - Merrill-Cazier Library
Article Text:
%newline%Explore the origins of the Bear Lake Monster legend in this digital collection featuring folklore items%comma% newspaper articles%comma% interviews and other materials from Utah State University’s Special Collections and Archives. The Bear Lake Monster is a regional legend from the Bear Lake Valley (Utah and Idaho)%comma% home to a large%comma% deep lake where the monster purportedly resides. Many believe the legend originated in 1896 with Joseph Rich%comma% an early Mormon settler and developer of the area who used the legend as a marketing ploy to get visitors to Rich County%comma% Utah (named for his family); he later said it was a joke. Joke or no%comma% the legend persists to date and has grown to include a connection to the Loch Ness Monster in Scotland. For many locals%comma% the legend serves as a cautionary water tale and well-known local joke.

Folklorist Elaine Thatcher notes: “My research in the Bear Lake Valley shows that the monster story has now evolved into self-parody%comma% as locals play with the story%comma% for themselves and for tourists” (Between Pulpit and Pew%comma% ix).

%newline%
AMP Image Version: <amp-img src="../images/collection_images/collection2137.jpg" alt="%return%%newline%Painting of Bear Lake Monster%return%%newline%" width="300" height ="250" layout = "responsive"></amp-img>
Image Description: Painting of Bear Lake monster

Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%A contributor from the Arizona Memory Project

%newline%The Arizona Heritage Commemorative Portrait Collection was generously donated to the Arizona State Capitol Museum in October 1982 by the Chris-Town Chamber of Commerce and the merchants of the Chris-Town Shopping Center. This collection was commissioned by the merchants of the Chris-Town Shopping Center for the enjoyment of all Arizonans.

%newline%These 24 original oil-pencil portraits by Roger Whitney honor people who contributed to the growth and development of Arizona. Each picture reflects the person's major area of interest and influence on our state's heritage. Chris-Town gratefully acknowledged research assistance from the Central Arizona Museum of History%comma% the Arizona State Capitol Museum and the Arizona Department of Education. The research helped determine the interests and contributions of each of the subjects. Whitney%comma% a well-known Phoenix artist%comma% often worked from photos to portray both Arizonan and national sports figures in his work.

Article Text:

Clayton Tullis Utah State Capitol Collection began when the donor%comma% Mr. Tullis%comma% volunteered as a tour guide at the Utah State Capitol.  Mr. Tullis has been interested in the Utah State Capitol building for many years and began to collect anything relating to the capitol building%comma% its history%comma% construction%comma% and the people who played a role in its development and construction.  

%newline%The collection currently consists of vintage postcards from the early twentieth century and a lithograph of the capitol building from the Governor's Office%comma% commissioned to commemorate the Utah Centennial in 1996.

Title: Cache County (UT) Aerial Photograph Collection
Publisher: Published by Utah State University - Merrill-Cazier Library
Article Text:
%newline%The Cache County Aerial Photograph Collection consists of high altitude images probably taken in 1952 and 1959 by the Aerial Photography Field Office in Salt Lake City. Before 1978 a number of federal agencies conducted high altitude surveys. In 1978 the National High Altitude Photography program was created to consolidate federal high altitude photography activities to save money. The images in this collection were probably used as part of the Soil Conservation Survey.

%newline%The collection also includes images of Cache County%comma% as well as images along the Cache/Box Elder County and the Cache/Weber County boundaries in Utah and from Oneida and Franklin County on the Utah/Idaho border. These images are from 9" x 9" negatives and taken at 1:20%comma%000. The date the image was taken is usually in the upper left-hand corner.

%newline%
AMP Image Version: <amp-img src="../images/collection_images/collection2165.jpg" alt="%return%%newline%Aerial photographs covering an area from Lewiston and the Utah/Idaho border%comma% 1959%return%%newline%" width="300" height ="250" layout = "responsive"></amp-img>
Image Description: Aerial photographs covering an area from Lewiston and the Utah/Idaho border%comma% 1959
Browse Link: %newline%Browse all records in Cache County (UT) Aerial Photograph Collection

Note: 2169.php has been marked for review (Null partner)
Title: - Collection in the Mountain West Digital Library
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%The Robert Lenon Map Collection consists of maps from the collection of Patagonia%comma% Arizona-based mining engineer Robert Lenon. The majority of these maps depict ore and mineral mining in the Sonoran desert region of southern Arizona and northern Mexico%comma% spanning the Arizona territorial period of the 1800s up to the 1960s. Additional selections include historical maps of the region%comma% including an 1880 Nogales city block map by Henry Flipper%comma% and maps drawn by Lenon tracing Father Eusebio Kino's route through Pimeria Alta in the 17th century. This digital collection represents just a small sample of the 9000 maps collected or created by Lenon over the course of his long and varied career.

%newline%A 1930 graduate of the Department of Mining and Geological Engineering at the University of Arizona%comma% Robert Lenon practiced as a mining engineer and surveyor for more than forty years%comma% retiring in 1975. His career in mining was interrupted by a five-year stint in the US Armed Forces during WWII%comma% where he served in both the European and Pacific theaters. In later years%comma% Lenon was an active supporter of the Arizona Historical Society and published two volumes of memoirs documenting his years in the Arizona mining industry. He died at the age of 99 in 2008.

%newline%This project was made possible through the generous support of The Walton Family Foundation.

%newline%
AMP Image Version: <amp-img src="../images/collection_images/collection2169.jpg" alt="%return%%newline%Haff and Colwell Group Map of the Tom Reed Gold Road District%comma% Mohave County Arizona%comma% 1916%return%%newline%" width="300" height ="250" layout = "responsive"></amp-img>

Title: Utah Technical College Women's Association Scrapbooks
Publisher: Published by Utah Valley University Library
Article Text:
%newline%This is a collection of scrapbooks compiled by the Utah Technical College Women's Association. This organization%comma% called UTC Women for short%comma% was organized in May 1969 to support faculty%comma% staff and students at Utah Technical College.

%newline%Membership consisted of the wives of UTC faculty and staff%comma% as well as women serving on the faculty and staff of the college. The scrapbooks contain memorabilia of the various arts%comma% humanities%comma% and professional programs and socials held by the group%comma% as well as that of their services to the community and the college.

Title: Montana State University (MSU) Historical Photographs Collection
Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%

The Montana State University Archives holds over 34%comma%000 volumes and 1%comma%200 linear feet of archive manuscript materials. In addition to the manuscript materials%comma% there are also archived microforms%comma% sound recordings%comma% film and video recordings%comma% unique maps and historical photographs. Over 4%comma%000 of these historical photographs are of Montana State University from 1893 through the 1960s. These unique MSU historical photos include early 20th century campus student activities and clubs%comma% campus grounds and buildings%comma% historical events%comma% and prominent alumni%comma% faculty%comma% and administrators.

%newline%

In 2012%comma% Montana State University Archives and Montana State University Library Digital Initiatives launched the Montana State University (MSU) Historical Photographs Database Project%comma% an on-going%comma% long-term project focused on providing Montana State University historical photographs online and in easily accessible downloadable JPEG format.

Title: Brian Head Ski Resort Photographs
Publisher: Published by Southern Utah University - Sherratt Library
Article Text:
%newline%Brian Head Ski Resort was established in 1964%comma% and opened as a one chairlift resort. Currently the resort has 8 chairlifts%comma% 71 runs%comma% and over 650 skiable acres. Brian Head is located 2.5 hours north of Las Vegas%comma% Nevada and four hours south of Salt Lake City%comma% Utah. The resort is Utah's highest elevation ski resort. Photographs from this collection show the ski resort as it was expanding and developing in the 1970's. Also included in the collection are photographs from the community of Parowan%comma% Utah%comma% gateway city to Brian Head Ski Resort.

Title: Historic Boise State Collection
Publisher: Published by Boise State University - Albertsons Library
Article Text:
%newline%

Boise State University's rich history is documented in the thousands of photographs%comma% slides%comma% and negatives that comprise the University Archives photo collection. From as far back as the school's opening day as Boise Junior College on September 6%comma% 1932%comma% photographers have captured on film the buildings%comma% people%comma% events%comma% and academic endeavors that have made Boise State University such an important part of the city of Boise and state of Idaho.

%newline%

Historic Boise State presents several hundred images that document the university's history. Most come from the print collection in the Archives and are concentrated in the decades from the 1930s to 2000s.

Title: H. Grant Ivins Papers
Publisher: Published by University of Utah - J. Willard Marriott Library
Article Text:
%newline%The H. Grant Ivins papers (1897-1973) contain diaries%comma% correspondence%comma% memoirs%comma% unpublished manuscripts%comma% and articles on subjects relating to religion and the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (LDS Church). This collection documents one man's transition from a devout believer in the divine authority of the members of the LDS Church hierarchy to an outspoken critic of those he later described to Heber Holt as "mere men who make mistakes and who should be willing to admit these mistakes."

%newline%

Title: Interviews with Jews in Utah
Publisher: Published by University of Utah - J. Willard Marriott Library
Article Text:
%newline%The interviews with Jews in Utah collection (1982-1988) is part of a project funded by the Utah Endowment for the Humanities and undertaken by the Oral History Institute of Salt Lake City%comma% Utah. Events recalled by the interviewees span the time period from the 1880s to 1986. Common themes include family life%comma% immigration%comma% relations with the LDS community%comma% religious activity%comma% the unification of the congregations Montefiore and B'nai Israel%comma% Jewish businesses and organizations%comma% and World War II.

Title: Telling Our Story: An Oral History of Utah Valley University
Publisher: Published by Utah Valley University Library
Article Text:
%newline%Telling Our Story-An Oral History of Utah Valley University is a growing collection of oral history interviews with long-time or retired employees of Utah Valley University. Interviewees in this collection include those who have worked at all of the different iterations of our school%comma% from the Central Utah Vocational School in 1942%comma% the Utah Trade Technical Institute%comma% Utah Technical College%comma% Utah Valley Community College%comma% Utah Valley State College%comma% and Utah Valley University.

%newline%This oral history%comma% which commemorates the 75th Anniversary of Utah Valley University in 2015%comma% will continue to grow with the addition of more interviews.

%newline%

Title: Everett L. Cooley Oral History Project
Publisher: Published by University of Utah - J. Willard Marriott Library
Article Text:
%newline%The Everett L. Cooley oral history project serves as a Who's Who in Utah. It features interviews with many who have played significant roles in Utah's history%comma% as well as others whose viewpoints and memories are important to understanding the history and the people of Utah.

%newline%A wide range of topics are discussed in the interviews%comma% including politics%comma% religion%comma% history%comma% education%comma% the University of Utah%comma% medicine%comma% art%comma% theater%comma% midwifery%comma% radio and television broadcasting%comma% sports%comma% entertainment%comma% genealogy%comma% dancing%comma% science%comma% women's issues%comma% polio%comma% skiing%comma% nuclear power%comma% the environment%comma% and athletics. The interviews were mostly conducted in the mid 1980s%comma% but range from 1960 to 2014. Time periods discussed in the interviews begin with the end of the 19th century.

%newline%
AMP Image Version: <amp-img src="../images/collection_images/collection2223.jpg" alt="Christopher Begue and Melissa Moeinvaziri%comma% Salt Lake City%comma% Utah: an interview by John Worsencroft%comma% 4 March 2009" height="300" width="250" layout = "responsive"></amp-img>

Title: Joseph Ellis Johnson Papers
Publisher: Published by University of Utah - J. Willard Marriott Library
Article Text:
%newline%The Joseph Ellis Johnson papers (1831-1964) consist of the personal and family papers of Joseph E. Johnson (1817-1882). Johnson was a prolific writer%comma% leaving a legacy of seven original diaries written%comma% at broken intervals%comma% between 1850 and 1876. The diaries give detailed accounts of his various travels. The collection also contains his daybooks%comma% account books%comma% and record books.

%newline%Correspondence between members of the Johnson family makes up a great part of the collection. From his travels%comma% Johnson wrote many letters%comma% sending his love and instructions to his wives and children%comma% and also wrote to his hired help who were running his business establishments. Johnson and his third wife%comma% Eliza%comma% corresponded most frequently as conditions prevented them from living in the same locality until they arrived in Utah.

%newline%

Browse Link: %newline%Browse all records in Joseph Ellis Johnson Papers

Title: Thomas Jefferson O'Brien Journals
Publisher: Published by University of Utah - J. Willard Marriott Library
Article Text:
%newline% The Thomas Jefferson O'Brien journals were kept during his mission to Australasia for the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints at the end of the nineteenth century. His journal relates his activities with the Maori on the Northern Island of New Zealand. The first volume covers the period from November 1893 to early February 1895. The second volume covers the period from February 1895 to January 1896.

%newline%

Title: MS 002 Victor Arland Collection
Publisher: Published by Buffalo Bill Center of the West%comma% McCracken Research Library
Article Text:
%newline%This collection consists of a series of original letters written by Victor Arland (c. 1848- 1890) of Arland%comma% Wyoming to Mr. C.P. Dadant of Hamilton%comma% IL%comma% a beekeeper and manufacturer of bee supplies and distributor of honey. The letters are handwritten in French%comma% dated between 1872 and 1889%comma% and for the most part are in good to excellent condition. The letters have been flattened%comma% separated by acid-free%comma% lignin-free paper in archival folders and housed in Box 1%comma% organized as Series 1. Included in Series 2 are excerpts of essays that have resulted from research with this collection.

%newline%

Title: MS 007 George Armstrong Custer Collection
Publisher: Published by Buffalo Bill Center of the West%comma% McCracken Research Library
Article Text:
%newline%This collection contains various documents concerning the Battle of the Little Big Horn. Most prominent are two original reports of General Alfred H. Terry to General George Crook%comma% the first official reports of the defeat of Custer at the Little Big Horn battlefield. Other documents in the collection include reminiscences of Wilmot Sanford on the battle%comma% a letter from General E. S. Godfrey to E.S. Paxson about the battle%comma% as well as a letter from William F. Cody to Elizabeth Custer regarding a statue of her husband.

%newline%

Browse Link: %newline%Browse all records in MS 007 George Armstrong Custer Collection

Title: MS 010 Count Otto Franc Von Lichtenstein Collection
Publisher: Published by Buffalo Bill Center of the West%comma% McCracken Research Library
Article Text:
%newline%Collection consists of four journals by Count Otto Franc von Liechtenstein relating daily activities as he ran the Pitchfork Ranch on the upper Greybull River west of present day Meeteetse%comma% Wyoming. Typed transcripts are present for the first two journals.

%newline%Born in Germany in 1846%comma% Count Otto Franc von Liechtenstein came to America in 1866. He first traveled to Wyoming in 1878. In 1879 he set up his first cattle operation in the Meeteetse area with cattle that he brought in from Montana. Pitchfork Ranch was the first cattle ranch in the Greybull River valley%comma% and its success led Franc to become a major Wyoming cattle baron.

%newline%Later in life%comma% in the 1890s Franc served as a Big Horn County justice of the peace. He is remembered for sentencing Butch Cassidy to the Wyoming state prison for two years for horse theft. Franc died in 1903.

%newline%
AMP Image Version: <amp-img src="../images/collection_images/collection2273.jpg" alt="Journal #1 of Count Otto Franc von Lichtenstein from the Pitchfork Ranch" width="409" height ="250" layout = "responsive"></amp-img>
Image Description: Journal #1 of Count Otto Franc von Lichtenstein from the Pitchfork Ranch
Browse Link: %newline%Browse all records in MS 010 Count Otto Franc Von Lichtenstein Collection

Title: MS 017 Charles Rapp Collection
Publisher: Published by Buffalo Bill Center of the West%comma% McCracken Research Library
Article Text:
%newline%This collection consists of the 15 letters from Charles Rapp to Eva Shepard written from various locations in Wyoming Territory. Mr. Rapp%comma% of New York%comma% discusses gold mining%comma% women homesteaders on the frontier%comma% Mormon immigration%comma% Shoshone and Sioux Indians%comma% and a description of a visit to the Little Big Horn battlefield three days after the battle.

%newline%Charles Rapp was a New Yorker who came to Wyoming during the short-lived gold rush period. The collection contains 15 letters%comma% written to a friend back home%comma% that describe life in early Wyoming and in the mining camps. Among the topics discussed are relations with the Indians%comma% the Battle of Little Big Horn%comma% and his feelings of home sickness.

%newline%

Image Description: Letter from Charles Rapp to Libbia Shepard
Browse Link: %newline%Browse all records in MS 017 Charles Rapp Collection

Publisher: Published by
Article Text:
%newline%Maya Miller was as an inspiration and mentor to an entire generation of political activists%comma% progressive thinkers%comma% feminists%comma% and those interested in social justice. Her papers are a representation of her commitment to the rights and well-being of the disadvantaged and disenfranchised in her home state of Nevada and abroad. In 2014%comma% the last of Maya Miller’s papers were donated to the University of Nevada%comma% Reno’s Special Collections%comma% along with a generous grant from the family’s Orchard House Foundation in order to prepare the collection for use.

Title: MS 247 Fred R. Meyer Photographs
Publisher: Published by Buffalo Bill Center of the West%comma% McCracken Research Library
Article Text:
%newline%46 black and white photographic prints of Blackfeet%comma% Cree%comma% Crow%comma% and Sioux peoples taken 1902-1904 by Fred R. Meyer%comma% a photographer from Buffalo%comma% NY. Includes scenes of the burial of Chief Plenty Coups and of Crow tribal member Pretty Horse Right Hand; a 1902 Blackfeet medicine lodge at Browning%comma% Montana with Chiefs Three Bears%comma% Rocky Boy%comma% Wolf Eagle%comma% Old Mountain Chief%comma% Many Guns%comma% Little Dog and Many Tail Feathers; and images of the Pine Ridge Sioux including Chief Red Cloud%comma% Two Moons%comma% Crazy Horse%comma% Chief Calico and his wife Good Dog%comma% and Black Horn. Also includes a few photographs of the Little Big Horn battlefield memorial. All caption quotations are from text written by Fred Meyer on the back of the photographic prints as sent to his friend William P. Sargent.

Title: Utah Territorial Secretary Territorial Executive Papers
Publisher: Published by Utah State Archives
Article Text:
%newline%The territorial secretary was responsible for recording all acts and proceedings of the Governor in his executive department and to provide copies of these official acts to specific federal officials. Over half of the series represent official acts of the Governor. Many other duties of the secretary are also documented%comma% most reflecting routine administrative functions of the territorial government.

Title: Utah Third District Case File Index
Publisher: Published by Utah State Archives
Article Text:
%newline%The territorial Case Index records the names of plaintiffs and defendants involved in court actions and provides assigned case numbers%comma% facilitating clerical management of and access to the case files. Civil cases span the entire period (1871-1896). Criminal cases were indexed in this series from 1871 to 1882%comma% when a separate filing arrangement for criminal case files was implemented.

Title: Utah Governor William Spry (1909-1917) Joseph Hillstrom Case Records
Publisher: Published by Utah State Archives
Article Text:
%newline% As chief executive officer of the state%comma% Governor Spry had the authority to commute the sentences of those convicted of crimes. The murder conviction and execution of Joseph Hillstrom (Joe Hill) became one of the most controversial criminal cases in Utah history; it generated national and international interest. These records were collected by the Governor's office during the time of the controversy.

%newline%

Title: Utah Governor William Spry (1909-1917) Joseph Hillstrom Correspondence
Publisher: Published by Utah State Archives
Article Text:
%newline%As chief executive officer of the state%comma% the governor has the authority to commute the sentences of those convicted of crimes. The conviction and execution of Joseph Hillstrom (Joe Hill) became one of the most controversial criminal cases in Utah history; it generated national and international interest. Correspondence is in the form of letters%comma% postcards%comma% and telegrams. Letters were sent to Governor Spry's office protesting the execution and/or conviction of Hill for the gunshot murders of J.S. Morrison and his son Arling.

%newline%

%newline%As chief executive officer of the state%comma% Governor Spry had the authority to commute the sentences of those convicted of crimes. The conviction and execution of Joseph Hillstrom (Joe Hill) became one of the most controversial criminal cases in Utah history; it generated national and international interest. Petitions were sent to Governor Spry's office protesting the planned execution and/or conviction of Hill for the gunshot murders of grocer J.S. Morrison and his son Arling.

Title: Utah State Capitol Building
Publisher: Published by Utah State Archives
Article Text:
%newline%To pursue the legislative mandate to "erect a suitable building" to serve as the Utah state capitol%comma% the Capitol Commission issued a call for construction bids to contractors and artisans. This series contains the bids submitted to the commission by those seeking employment. The collection includes bids for furnishings%comma% heating and ventilating systems%comma% elevators%comma% vaults%comma% cuspidors%comma% lighting%comma% and numerous others. The series also documents inquiries from contractors to the Capitol Commission regarding the bidding process%comma% contracts%comma% operational budgets%comma% and contract decisions. The bids include information on Utah craftsmen%comma% architects%comma% and contractors%comma% and significant information about construction techniques%comma% planning%comma% bidding processes%comma% and labor and material costs from the period.

%newline%
AMP Image Version: <amp-img src="../images/collection_images/collection2298.jpg" alt="Design Submissions%comma% Submission by J. E. Tourtellote & Co." height ="250" width="250" layout = "responsive"></amp-img>

Browse Link: %newline%Browse all records in Utah State Capitol Building

Title: Western Shoshone Defense Project
Publisher: Published by University of Nevada%comma% Reno%comma% University Libraries
Article Text:
%newline%The records of the Western Shoshone Defense Project were maintained by sisters Carrie and Mary Dann%comma% two traditional Western Shoshone ranchers living in northeastern Nevada. The Defense Project's mission was to affirm Western Shoshone jurisdiction over Western Shoshone ancestral homelands by protecting%comma% preserving%comma% and restoring Shoshone rights and lands for present and future generations based on cultural and spiritual traditions. It was established in 1991 by the Western Shoshone National Council to provide support to Mary and Carrie Dann as they faced confiscation of their livestock which they grazed on Western Shoshone homelands without paying grazing fees to the Bureau of Land Management.

%newline%

Title: Maya Miller Papers
Publisher: Published by University of Nevada%comma% Reno%comma% University Libraries
Article Text:
%newline%Maya Miller was as an inspiration and mentor to an entire generation of political activists%comma% progressive thinkers%comma% feminists%comma% and those interested in social justice. Her papers are a representation of her commitment to the rights and well-being of the disadvantaged and disenfranchised in her home state of Nevada and abroad. In 2014%comma% the last of Maya Miller’s papers were donated to the University of Nevada%comma% Reno’s Special Collections%comma% along with a generous grant from the family’s Orchard House Foundation in order to prepare the collection for use.

%newline%

Title: Paul Laxalt and Ronald Reagan
Publisher: Published by University of Nevada%comma% Reno%comma% University Libraries
Article Text:
%newline%Paul Laxalt was a longtime public figure in Nevada and beginning in the mid-1970s%comma% he became a notable and highly visible player on the national political stage. Part of Laxalt’s appeal to both his colleagues and his constituents was his pragmatic and unapologetic approach to lawmaking. The son of Basque immigrants%comma% Laxalt rose through the local political ranks before becoming the first Basque-American ever elected to the U.S. Senate and “the First Friend” of Ronald Reagan.

%newline%The Ronald Reagan materials within the Paul Laxalt U.S. Senatorial Papers cover the years 1975 through 1987. They consist of a variety of personal papers%comma% scrapbooks%comma% audio/visual resources%comma% and photographs from Reagan’s three presidential campaigns in which Laxalt served as the national chairman. Presented here is a small selection of these items that have been digitized and organized according to themes that reflect both Laxalt’s political career and his relationship with Ronald Reagan.

%newline%

Title: Ellis Reynolds Shipp Papers
Publisher: Published by Department of Heritage and Arts
Article Text:
%newline%The Ellis Reynolds Shipp papers came to the Historical Society in two installments (1967 and 1973) as a gift of the children of Joseph White and Ellis Shipp Musser. Besides the Shipp material%comma% a quantity of Musser family material was also donated. The Shipp papers are completely open to researchers. Dr. Shipp's papers contain a great deal of correspondence%comma% all original holographs. It has been arranged according to writer%comma% then chronologically. The biggest division is%comma% of course%comma% that of Ellis Shipp herself. There are smaller groups of letters written by her children%comma% husband%comma% and his other wives.

%newline% Another major part of the collection is the poetry of Dr. Shipp. She wrote verses continually for most of her life and published a volume of her poetry in 1910%comma% titled Life Lines. She also wrote a poem for Christmas each year as a Christmas card. Besides poetry and correspondence%comma% the collection includes a great deal of biographical material on the Shipps and Hawleys. There are also examples of diaries kept by Dr. Shipp%comma% as well as several editions of her autobiography which was compiled and published by Ellis Shipp Musser in 1962.

%newline%Subjects covered%comma% at varying depths%comma% by the Shipp papers include early medical practice%comma% genealogy and family history%comma% polygamy%comma% and life in nineteenth and early twentieth century Utah.

%newline%

Title: MS 5 - Cody Local History Collection
Publisher: Published by Buffalo Bill Center of the West%comma% McCracken Research Library
Article Text:
%newline%Cody%comma% Wyoming was founded in 1895. Long associated with William F. Cody and the East Entrance to Yellowstone Park%comma% Cody has had a rich and varied past. Series within the collection have been set up on the history of the City of Cody and Park County%comma% which include Cody Rod and Gun Club papers; W. F. Cody; Wyoming and Western U.S. history; local persons and families such as Elmore Jones and the Hargreave family; general city of Cody and local scenery and wildlife photographs (many photos still unidentified); and Cody newspapers that include the Heart Mountain Sentinel of the World War II Japanese-American internment camp.

%newline%
